--   <a>sourceSelectionCriteria_replicaModifications</a> - A filter that
--   you can specify for selections for modifications on replicas. Amazon
--   S3 doesn't replicate replica modifications by default. In the latest
--   version of replication configuration (when <tt>Filter</tt> is
--   specified), you can specify this element and set the status to
--   <tt>Enabled</tt> to replicate modifications on replicas.
--   
--   If you don't specify the <tt>Filter</tt> element, Amazon S3 assumes
--   that the replication configuration is the earlier version, V1. In the
--   earlier version, this element is not allowed
--   
--   <a>$sel:sseKmsEncryptedObjects:SourceSelectionCriteria'</a>,
--   <a>sourceSelectionCriteria_sseKmsEncryptedObjects</a> - A container
--   for filter information for the selection of Amazon S3 objects
--   encrypted with Amazon Web Services KMS. If you include
--   <tt>SourceSelectionCriteria</tt> in the replication configuration,
--   this element is required.
newSourceSelectionCriteria :: SourceSelectionCriteria

-- | A filter that you can specify for selections for modifications on
--   replicas. Amazon S3 doesn't replicate replica modifications by
--   default. In the latest version of replication configuration (when
--   <tt>Filter</tt> is specified), you can specify this element and set
--   the status to <tt>Enabled</tt> to replicate modifications on replicas.
--

--   that the replication configuration is the earlier version, V1. In the
--   earlier version, this element is not allowed
sourceSelectionCriteria_replicaModifications :: Lens' SourceSelectionCriteria (Maybe ReplicaModifications)

-- | A container for filter information for the selection of Amazon S3
--   objects encrypted with Amazon Web Services KMS. If you include
--   <tt>SourceSelectionCriteria</tt> in the replication configuration,
--   this element is required.
sourceSelectionCriteria_sseKmsEncryptedObjects :: Lens' SourceSelectionCriteria (Maybe SseKmsEncryptedObjects)

--   encrypted with Amazon Web Services KMS.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newSseKmsEncryptedObjects</a> smart constructor.

-- | Container for the stats details.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newStats</a> smart constructor.
data Stats
Stats' :: Maybe Integer -> Maybe Integer -> Maybe Integer -> Stats

-- | The total number of bytes of records payload data returned.
[$sel:bytesReturned:Stats'] :: Stats -> Maybe Integer

-- | The total number of object bytes scanned.
[$sel:bytesScanned:Stats'] :: Stats -> Maybe Integer

-- | The total number of uncompressed object bytes processed.
[$sel:bytesProcessed:Stats'] :: Stats -> Maybe Integer

-- | Create a value of <a>Stats</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:bytesReturned:Stats'</a>, <a>stats_bytesReturned</a> - The
--   total number of bytes of records payload data returned.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bytesScanned:Stats'</a>, <a>stats_bytesScanned</a> - The total
--   number of object bytes scanned.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bytesProcessed:Stats'</a>, <a>stats_bytesProcessed</a> - The
--   total number of uncompressed object bytes processed.
newStats :: Stats

-- | The total number of bytes of records payload data returned.
stats_bytesReturned :: Lens' Stats (Maybe Integer)

-- | The total number of object bytes scanned.
stats_bytesScanned :: Lens' Stats (Maybe Integer)

-- | The total number of uncompressed object bytes processed.
stats_bytesProcessed :: Lens' Stats (Maybe Integer)

-- | Container for the Stats Event.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newStatsEvent</a> smart constructor.
data StatsEvent
StatsEvent' :: Maybe Stats -> StatsEvent

-- | The Stats event details.
[$sel:details:StatsEvent'] :: StatsEvent -> Maybe Stats

-- | Create a value of <a>StatsEvent</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.

--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:

--   event details.
newStatsEvent :: StatsEvent

-- | The Stats event details.
statsEvent_details :: Lens' StatsEvent (Maybe Stats)

-- | The S3 Intelligent-Tiering storage class is designed to optimize
--   storage costs by automatically moving data to the most cost-effective
--   storage access tier, without additional operational overhead.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newTiering</a> smart constructor.
data Tiering
Tiering' :: Int -> IntelligentTieringAccessTier -> Tiering

-- | The number of consecutive days of no access after which an object will
--   be eligible to be transitioned to the corresponding tier. The minimum
--   number of days specified for Archive Access tier must be at least 90
--   days and Deep Archive Access tier must be at least 180 days. The
--   maximum can be up to 2 years (730 days).
[$sel:days:Tiering'] :: Tiering -> Int

-- | S3 Intelligent-Tiering access tier. See <a>Storage class for
--   automatically optimizing frequently and infrequently accessed
--   objects</a> for a list of access tiers in the S3 Intelligent-Tiering
--   storage class.
[$sel:accessTier:Tiering'] :: Tiering -> IntelligentTieringAccessTier

-- | Create a value of <a>Tiering</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:days:Tiering'</a>, <a>tiering_days</a> - The number of
--   consecutive days of no access after which an object will be eligible
--   to be transitioned to the corresponding tier. The minimum number of
--   days specified for Archive Access tier must be at least 90 days and
--   Deep Archive Access tier must be at least 180 days. The maximum can be
--   up to 2 years (730 days).
--   
--   <a>$sel:accessTier:Tiering'</a>, <a>tiering_accessTier</a> - S3
--   Intelligent-Tiering access tier. See <a>Storage class for
--   automatically optimizing frequently and infrequently accessed
--   objects</a> for a list of access tiers in the S3 Intelligent-Tiering
--   storage class.
newTiering :: Int -> IntelligentTieringAccessTier -> Tiering

-- | The number of consecutive days of no access after which an object will
--   be eligible to be transitioned to the corresponding tier. The minimum
--   number of days specified for Archive Access tier must be at least 90
--   days and Deep Archive Access tier must be at least 180 days. The
--   maximum can be up to 2 years (730 days).
tiering_days :: Lens' Tiering Int

-- | S3 Intelligent-Tiering access tier. See <a>Storage class for
--   automatically optimizing frequently and infrequently accessed
--   objects</a> for a list of access tiers in the S3 Intelligent-Tiering
--   storage class.
tiering_accessTier :: Lens' Tiering IntelligentTieringAccessTier

-- | A container for specifying the configuration for publication of
--   messages to an Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) topic
--   when Amazon S3 detects specified events.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newTopicConfiguration</a> smart constructor.
data TopicConfiguration
TopicConfiguration' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe NotificationConfigurationFilter -> Text -> [Event] -> TopicConfiguration
[$sel:id:TopicConfiguration'] :: TopicConfiguration -> Maybe Text
[$sel:filter':TopicConfiguration'] :: TopicConfiguration -> Maybe NotificationConfigurationFilter

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Amazon SNS topic to which Amazon
--   S3 publishes a message when it detects events of the specified type.
[$sel:topicArn:TopicConfiguration'] :: TopicConfiguration -> Text

-- | The Amazon S3 bucket event about which to send notifications. For more
--   information, see <a>Supported Event Types</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User
--   Guide</i>.
[$sel:events:TopicConfiguration'] :: TopicConfiguration -> [Event]

-- | Create a value of <a>TopicConfiguration</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.

--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:

--   detects events of the specified type.
--   
--   <a>$sel:events:TopicConfiguration'</a>,

--   which to send notifications. For more information, see <a>Supported
--   Event Types</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
newTopicConfiguration :: Text -> TopicConfiguration

--   S3 publishes a message when it detects events of the specified type.
topicConfiguration_topicArn :: Lens' TopicConfiguration Text

--   information, see <a>Supported Event Types</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User
--   Guide</i>.
topicConfiguration_events :: Lens' TopicConfiguration [Event]

-- | Specifies when an object transitions to a specified storage class. For
--   more information about Amazon S3 lifecycle configuration rules, see
--   <a>Transitioning Objects Using Amazon S3 Lifecycle</a> in the
--   <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newTransition</a> smart constructor.
data Transition
Transition' :: Maybe Int -> Maybe ISO8601 -> Maybe TransitionStorageClass -> Transition

-- | Indicates the number of days after creation when objects are
--   transitioned to the specified storage class. The value must be a
--   positive integer.
[$sel:days:Transition'] :: Transition -> Maybe Int

-- | Indicates when objects are transitioned to the specified storage
--   class. The date value must be in ISO 8601 format. The time is always
--   midnight UTC.
[$sel:date:Transition'] :: Transition -> Maybe ISO8601

-- | The storage class to which you want the object to transition.
[$sel:storageClass:Transition'] :: Transition -> Maybe TransitionStorageClass

-- | Create a value of <a>Transition</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:days:Transition'</a>, <a>transition_days</a> - Indicates the
--   number of days after creation when objects are transitioned to the
--   specified storage class. The value must be a positive integer.
--   
--   <a>$sel:date:Transition'</a>, <a>transition_date</a> - Indicates when
--   objects are transitioned to the specified storage class. The date
--   value must be in ISO 8601 format. The time is always midnight UTC.
--   
--   <a>$sel:storageClass:Transition'</a>, <a>transition_storageClass</a> -
--   The storage class to which you want the object to transition.
newTransition :: Transition

-- | Indicates the number of days after creation when objects are
--   transitioned to the specified storage class. The value must be a
--   positive integer.
transition_days :: Lens' Transition (Maybe Int)

-- | Indicates when objects are transitioned to the specified storage
--   class. The date value must be in ISO 8601 format. The time is always
--   midnight UTC.
transition_date :: Lens' Transition (Maybe UTCTime)

-- | The storage class to which you want the object to transition.
transition_storageClass :: Lens' Transition (Maybe TransitionStorageClass)

-- | Describes the versioning state of an Amazon S3 bucket. For more

data VersioningConfiguration

--   delete is enabled in the bucket versioning configuration. This element

--   the bucket has never been so configured, this element is not returned.
newVersioningConfiguration :: VersioningConfiguration

versioningConfiguration_mfaDelete :: Lens' VersioningConfiguration (Maybe MFADelete)

data WebsiteConfiguration

--   endpoint.

--   If you specify this property, you can't specify any other property.
[$sel:redirectAllRequestsTo:WebsiteConfiguration'] :: WebsiteConfiguration -> Maybe RedirectAllRequestsTo

-- | The name of the error document for the website.
[$sel:errorDocument:WebsiteConfiguration'] :: WebsiteConfiguration -> Maybe ErrorDocument

[$sel:indexDocument:WebsiteConfiguration'] :: WebsiteConfiguration -> Maybe IndexDocument

--   behavior.
[$sel:routingRules:WebsiteConfiguration'] :: WebsiteConfiguration -> Maybe [RoutingRule]

--   behavior.

-- | This action filters the contents of an Amazon S3 object based on a
--   simple structured query language (SQL) statement. In the request,
--   along with the SQL expression, you must also specify a data
--   serialization format (JSON, CSV, or Apache Parquet) of the object.
--   Amazon S3 uses this format to parse object data into records, and
--   returns only records that match the specified SQL expression. You must
--   also specify the data serialization format for the response.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
--   
--   For more information about Amazon S3 Select, see <a>Selecting Content
--   from Objects</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   For more information about using SQL with Amazon S3 Select, see <a>SQL
--   Reference for Amazon S3 Select and S3 Glacier Select</a> in the
--   <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <b>Permissions</b>
--   
--   You must have <tt>s3:GetObject</tt> permission for this operation.
--   Amazon S3 Select does not support anonymous access. For more
--   information about permissions, see <a>Specifying Permissions in a
--   Policy</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <i>Object Data Formats</i>
--   
--   You can use Amazon S3 Select to query objects that have the following
--   format properties:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><i>CSV, JSON, and Parquet</i> - Objects must be in CSV, JSON, or
--   Parquet format.</li>
--   <li><i>UTF-8</i> - UTF-8 is the only encoding type Amazon S3 Select
--   supports.</li>
--   <li><i>GZIP or BZIP2</i> - CSV and JSON files can be compressed using
--   GZIP or BZIP2. GZIP and BZIP2 are the only compression formats that
--   Amazon S3 Select supports for CSV and JSON files. Amazon S3 Select
--   supports columnar compression for Parquet using GZIP or Snappy. Amazon
--   S3 Select does not support whole-object compression for Parquet
--   objects.</li>
--   <li><i>Server-side encryption</i> - Amazon S3 Select supports querying
--   objects that are protected with server-side encryption.For objects
--   that are encrypted with customer-provided encryption keys (SSE-C), you
--   must use HTTPS, and you must use the headers that are documented in
--   the <a>GetObject</a>. For more information about SSE-C, see
--   <a>Server-Side Encryption (Using Customer-Provided Encryption
--   Keys)</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.For objects that are
--   encrypted with Amazon S3 managed encryption keys (SSE-S3) and Amazon
--   Web Services KMS keys (SSE-KMS), server-side encryption is handled
--   transparently, so you don't need to specify anything. For more
--   information about server-side encryption, including SSE-S3 and
--   SSE-KMS, see <a>Protecting Data Using Server-Side Encryption</a> in
--   the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <b>Working with the Response Body</b>
--   
--   Given the response size is unknown, Amazon S3 Select streams the
--   response as a series of messages and includes a
--   <tt>Transfer-Encoding</tt> header with <tt>chunked</tt> as its value
--   in the response. For more information, see <a>Appendix:
--   SelectObjectContent Response</a>.
--   
--   <b>GetObject Support</b>
--   
--   The <tt>SelectObjectContent</tt> action does not support the following
--   <tt>GetObject</tt> functionality. For more information, see
--   <a>GetObject</a>.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>Range</tt>: Although you can specify a scan range for an
--   Amazon S3 Select request (see <a>SelectObjectContentRequest -
--   ScanRange</a> in the request parameters), you cannot specify the range
--   of bytes of an object to return.</li>
--   <li>GLACIER, DEEP_ARCHIVE and REDUCED_REDUNDANCY storage classes: You
--   cannot specify the GLACIER, DEEP_ARCHIVE, or
--   <tt>REDUCED_REDUNDANCY</tt> storage classes. For more information,
--   about storage classes see <a>Storage Classes</a> in the <i>Amazon S3
--   User Guide</i>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <b>Special Errors</b>
--   
--   For a list of special errors for this operation, see <a>List of SELECT
--   Object Content Error Codes</a>
--   
--   <b>Related Resources</b>
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><a>GetObject</a></li>
--   <li><a>GetBucketLifecycleConfiguration</a></li>
--   <li><a>PutBucketLifecycleConfiguration</a></li>
--   </ul>
module Network.AWS.S3.SelectObjectContent

-- | Request to filter the contents of an Amazon S3 object based on a
--   simple Structured Query Language (SQL) statement. In the request,
--   along with the SQL expression, you must specify a data serialization
--   format (JSON or CSV) of the object. Amazon S3 uses this to parse
--   object data into records. It returns only records that match the
--   specified SQL expression. You must also specify the data serialization
--   format for the response. For more information, see <a>S3Select API
--   Documentation</a>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newSelectObjectContent</a> smart constructor.
data SelectObjectContent
SelectObjectContent' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe (Sensitive Text) -> Maybe RequestProgress -> Maybe Text -> Maybe ScanRange -> Maybe Text -> BucketName -> ObjectKey -> Text -> ExpressionType -> InputSerialization -> OutputSerialization -> SelectObjectContent

-- | The SSE Algorithm used to encrypt the object. For more information,
--   see <a>Server-Side Encryption (Using Customer-Provided Encryption
--   Keys</a>.
[$sel:sSECustomerAlgorithm:SelectObjectContent'] :: SelectObjectContent -> Maybe Text

-- | The SSE Customer Key. For more information, see <a>Server-Side
--   Encryption (Using Customer-Provided Encryption Keys</a>.
[$sel:sSECustomerKey:SelectObjectContent'] :: SelectObjectContent -> Maybe (Sensitive Text)

-- | Specifies if periodic request progress information should be enabled.
[$sel:requestProgress:SelectObjectContent'] :: SelectObjectContent -> Maybe RequestProgress

-- | The SSE Customer Key MD5. For more information, see <a>Server-Side
--   Encryption (Using Customer-Provided Encryption Keys</a>.
[$sel:sSECustomerKeyMD5:SelectObjectContent'] :: SelectObjectContent -> Maybe Text

-- | Specifies the byte range of the object to get the records from. A
--   record is processed when its first byte is contained by the range.
--   This parameter is optional, but when specified, it must not be empty.
--   See RFC 2616, Section 14.35.1 about how to specify the start and end
--   of the range.
--   
--   <tt>ScanRange</tt>may be used in the following ways:
--   
--   <ul>
--   
--   <li><tt>&lt;scanrange&gt;&lt;start&gt;50&lt;/start&gt;&lt;end&gt;100&lt;/end&gt;&lt;/scanrange&gt;</tt>
--   - process only the records starting between the bytes 50 and 100
--   (inclusive, counting from zero)</li>
--   
--   <li><tt>&lt;scanrange&gt;&lt;start&gt;50&lt;/start&gt;&lt;/scanrange&gt;</tt>
--   - process only the records starting after the byte 50</li>
--   
--   <li><tt>&lt;scanrange&gt;&lt;end&gt;50&lt;/end&gt;&lt;/scanrange&gt;</tt>
--   - process only the records within the last 50 bytes of the file.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:scanRange:SelectObjectContent'] :: SelectObjectContent -> Maybe ScanRange

-- | The account ID of the expected bucket owner. If the bucket is owned by
--   a different account, the request will fail with an HTTP <tt>403
--   (Access Denied)</tt> error.
[$sel:expectedBucketOwner:SelectObjectContent'] :: SelectObjectContent -> Maybe Text

-- | The S3 bucket.
[$sel:bucket:SelectObjectContent'] :: SelectObjectContent -> BucketName

-- | The object key.
[$sel:key:SelectObjectContent'] :: SelectObjectContent -> ObjectKey

-- | The expression that is used to query the object.
[$sel:expression:SelectObjectContent'] :: SelectObjectContent -> Text

-- | The type of the provided expression (for example, SQL).
[$sel:expressionType:SelectObjectContent'] :: SelectObjectContent -> ExpressionType

-- | Describes the format of the data in the object that is being queried.
[$sel:inputSerialization:SelectObjectContent'] :: SelectObjectContent -> InputSerialization

-- | Describes the format of the data that you want Amazon S3 to return in
--   response.
[$sel:outputSerialization:SelectObjectContent'] :: SelectObjectContent -> OutputSerialization

-- | Create a value of <a>SelectObjectContent</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:sSECustomerAlgorithm:SelectObjectContent'</a>,
--   <a>selectObjectContent_sSECustomerAlgorithm</a> - The SSE Algorithm
--   used to encrypt the object. For more information, see <a>Server-Side
--   Encryption (Using Customer-Provided Encryption Keys</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sSECustomerKey:SelectObjectContent'</a>,
--   <a>selectObjectContent_sSECustomerKey</a> - The SSE Customer Key. For
--   more information, see <a>Server-Side Encryption (Using
--   Customer-Provided Encryption Keys</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:requestProgress:SelectObjectContent'</a>,
--   <a>selectObjectContent_requestProgress</a> - Specifies if periodic
--   request progress information should be enabled.

--   <a>$sel:sSECustomerKeyMD5:SelectObjectContent'</a>,
--   <a>selectObjectContent_sSECustomerKeyMD5</a> - The SSE Customer Key
--   MD5. For more information, see <a>Server-Side Encryption (Using
--   Customer-Provided Encryption Keys</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:scanRange:SelectObjectContent'</a>,
--   <a>selectObjectContent_scanRange</a> - Specifies the byte range of the
--   object to get the records from. A record is processed when its first
--   byte is contained by the range. This parameter is optional, but when
--   specified, it must not be empty. See RFC 2616, Section 14.35.1 about
--   how to specify the start and end of the range.
--   
--   <tt>ScanRange</tt>may be used in the following ways:
--   
--   <ul>
--   
--   <li><tt>&lt;scanrange&gt;&lt;start&gt;50&lt;/start&gt;&lt;end&gt;100&lt;/end&gt;&lt;/scanrange&gt;</tt>
--   - process only the records starting between the bytes 50 and 100
--   (inclusive, counting from zero)</li>
--   
--   <li><tt>&lt;scanrange&gt;&lt;start&gt;50&lt;/start&gt;&lt;/scanrange&gt;</tt>
--   - process only the records starting after the byte 50</li>
--   
--   <li><tt>&lt;scanrange&gt;&lt;end&gt;50&lt;/end&gt;&lt;/scanrange&gt;</tt>
--   - process only the records within the last 50 bytes of the file.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:expectedBucketOwner:SelectObjectContent'</a>,
--   <a>selectObjectContent_expectedBucketOwner</a> - The account ID of the
--   expected bucket owner. If the bucket is owned by a different account,
--   the request will fail with an HTTP <tt>403 (Access Denied)</tt> error.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bucket:SelectObjectContent'</a>,
--   <a>selectObjectContent_bucket</a> - The S3 bucket.
--   
--   <a>$sel:key:SelectObjectContent'</a>, <a>selectObjectContent_key</a> -
--   The object key.
--   
--   <a>$sel:expression:SelectObjectContent'</a>,
--   <a>selectObjectContent_expression</a> - The expression that is used to
--   query the object.
--   
--   <a>$sel:expressionType:SelectObjectContent'</a>,
--   <a>selectObjectContent_expressionType</a> - The type of the provided
--   expression (for example, SQL).
--   
--   <a>$sel:inputSerialization:SelectObjectContent'</a>,
--   <a>selectObjectContent_inputSerialization</a> - Describes the format
--   of the data in the object that is being queried.
--   
--   <a>$sel:outputSerialization:SelectObjectContent'</a>,
--   <a>selectObjectContent_outputSerialization</a> - Describes the format
--   of the data that you want Amazon S3 to return in response.
newSelectObjectContent :: BucketName -> ObjectKey -> Text -> ExpressionType -> InputSerialization -> OutputSerialization -> SelectObjectContent

--   record is processed when its first byte is contained by the range.
--   This parameter is optional, but when specified, it must not be empty.
--   See RFC 2616, Section 14.35.1 about how to specify the start and end
--   of the range.
--   
--   <tt>ScanRange</tt>may be used in the following ways:
--   
--   <ul>
--   
--   <li><tt>&lt;scanrange&gt;&lt;start&gt;50&lt;/start&gt;&lt;end&gt;100&lt;/end&gt;&lt;/scanrange&gt;</tt>
--   - process only the records starting between the bytes 50 and 100
--   (inclusive, counting from zero)</li>

--   <li><tt>&lt;scanrange&gt;&lt;start&gt;50&lt;/start&gt;&lt;/scanrange&gt;</tt>
--   - process only the records starting after the byte 50</li>
--   
--   <li><tt>&lt;scanrange&gt;&lt;end&gt;50&lt;/end&gt;&lt;/scanrange&gt;</tt>
--   - process only the records within the last 50 bytes of the file.</li>
--   </ul>
selectObjectContent_scanRange :: Lens' SelectObjectContent (Maybe ScanRange)

-- | Restores an archived copy of an object back into Amazon S3
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
--   
--   This action performs the following types of requests:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>select</tt> - Perform a select query on an archived
--   object</li>
--   <li><tt>restore an archive</tt> - Restore an archived object</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   To use this operation, you must have permissions to perform the
--   <tt>s3:RestoreObject</tt> action. The bucket owner has this permission
--   by default and can grant this permission to others. For more
--   information about permissions, see <a>Permissions Related to Bucket
--   Subresource Operations</a> and <a>Managing Access Permissions to Your
--   Amazon S3 Resources</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <b>Querying Archives with Select Requests</b>
--   
--   You use a select type of request to perform SQL queries on archived
--   objects. The archived objects that are being queried by the select
--   request must be formatted as uncompressed comma-separated values (CSV)
--   files. You can run queries and custom analytics on your archived data
--   without having to restore your data to a hotter Amazon S3 tier. For an
--   overview about select requests, see <a>Querying Archived Objects</a>
--   in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   When making a select request, do the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Define an output location for the select query's output. This must
--   be an Amazon S3 bucket in the same Amazon Web Services Region as the
--   bucket that contains the archive object that is being queried. The
--   Amazon Web Services account that initiates the job must have
--   permissions to write to the S3 bucket. You can specify the storage
--   class and encryption for the output objects stored in the bucket. For
--   more information about output, see <a>Querying Archived Objects</a> in
--   the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.For more information about the
--   <tt>S3</tt> structure in the request body, see the
--   following:<ul><li><a>PutObject</a></li><li><a>Managing Access with
--   ACLs</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i></li><li><a>Protecting Data
--   Using Server-Side Encryption</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User
--   Guide</i></li></ul></li>
--   <li>Define the SQL expression for the <tt>SELECT</tt> type of
--   restoration for your query in the request body's
--   <tt>SelectParameters</tt> structure. You can use expressions like the
--   following examples.<ul><li>The following expression returns all
--   records from the specified object.<pre>SELECT * FROM
--   Object</pre></li><li>Assuming that you are not using any headers for
--   data stored in the object, you can specify columns with positional
--   headers.<pre>SELECT s._1, s._2 FROM Object s WHERE s._3 &gt;
--   100</pre></li><li>If you have headers and you set the
--   <tt>fileHeaderInfo</tt> in the <tt>CSV</tt> structure in the request
--   body to <tt>USE</tt>, you can specify headers in the query. (If you
--   set the <tt>fileHeaderInfo</tt> field to <tt>IGNORE</tt>, the first
--   row is skipped for the query.) You cannot mix ordinal positions with
--   header column names.<pre>SELECT s.Id, s.FirstName, s.SSN FROM S3Object
--   s</pre></li></ul></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about using SQL with S3 Glacier Select restore,
--   see <a>SQL Reference for Amazon S3 Select and S3 Glacier Select</a> in
--   the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   When making a select request, you can also do the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>To expedite your queries, specify the <tt>Expedited</tt> tier. For
--   more information about tiers, see "Restoring Archives," later in this
--   topic.</li>
--   <li>Specify details about the data serialization format of both the
--   input object that is being queried and the serialization of the
--   CSV-encoded query results.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The following are additional important facts about the select feature:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>The output results are new Amazon S3 objects. Unlike archive
--   retrievals, they are stored until explicitly deleted-manually or
--   through a lifecycle policy.</li>
--   <li>You can issue more than one select request on the same Amazon S3
--   object. Amazon S3 doesn't deduplicate requests, so avoid issuing
--   duplicate requests.</li>
--   <li>Amazon S3 accepts a select request even if the object has already
--   been restored. A select request doesn’t return error response
--   <tt>409</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <b>Restoring objects</b>
--   
--   Objects that you archive to the S3 Glacier or S3 Glacier Deep Archive
--   storage class, and S3 Intelligent-Tiering Archive or S3
--   Intelligent-Tiering Deep Archive tiers are not accessible in real
--   time. For objects in Archive Access or Deep Archive Access tiers you
--   must first initiate a restore request, and then wait until the object
--   is moved into the Frequent Access tier. For objects in S3 Glacier or
--   S3 Glacier Deep Archive storage classes you must first initiate a
--   restore request, and then wait until a temporary copy of the object is
--   available. To access an archived object, you must restore the object
--   for the duration (number of days) that you specify.
--   
--   To restore a specific object version, you can provide a version ID. If
--   you don't provide a version ID, Amazon S3 restores the current
--   version.
--   
--   When restoring an archived object (or using a select request), you can
--   specify one of the following data access tier options in the
--   <tt>Tier</tt> element of the request body:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>Expedited</tt></b> - Expedited retrievals allow you to
--   quickly access your data stored in the S3 Glacier storage class or S3
--   Intelligent-Tiering Archive tier when occasional urgent requests for a
--   subset of archives are required. For all but the largest archived
--   objects (250 MB+), data accessed using Expedited retrievals is
--   typically made available within 1–5 minutes. Provisioned capacity
--   ensures that retrieval capacity for Expedited retrievals is available
--   when you need it. Expedited retrievals and provisioned capacity are
--   not available for objects stored in the S3 Glacier Deep Archive
--   storage class or S3 Intelligent-Tiering Deep Archive tier.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Standard</tt></b> - Standard retrievals allow you to access
--   any of your archived objects within several hours. This is the default
--   option for retrieval requests that do not specify the retrieval
--   option. Standard retrievals typically finish within 3–5 hours for
--   objects stored in the S3 Glacier storage class or S3
--   Intelligent-Tiering Archive tier. They typically finish within 12
--   hours for objects stored in the S3 Glacier Deep Archive storage class
--   or S3 Intelligent-Tiering Deep Archive tier. Standard retrievals are
--   free for objects stored in S3 Intelligent-Tiering.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Bulk</tt></b> - Bulk retrievals are the lowest-cost
--   retrieval option in S3 Glacier, enabling you to retrieve large
--   amounts, even petabytes, of data inexpensively. Bulk retrievals
--   typically finish within 5–12 hours for objects stored in the S3
--   Glacier storage class or S3 Intelligent-Tiering Archive tier. They
--   typically finish within 48 hours for objects stored in the S3 Glacier
--   Deep Archive storage class or S3 Intelligent-Tiering Deep Archive
--   tier. Bulk retrievals are free for objects stored in S3
--   Intelligent-Tiering.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about archive retrieval options and provisioned
--   capacity for <tt>Expedited</tt> data access, see <a>Restoring Archived
--   Objects</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   You can use Amazon S3 restore speed upgrade to change the restore
--   speed to a faster speed while it is in progress. For more information,
--   see <a>Upgrading the speed of an in-progress restore</a> in the
--   <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   To get the status of object restoration, you can send a <tt>HEAD</tt>
--   request. Operations return the <tt>x-amz-restore</tt> header, which
--   provides information about the restoration status, in the response.
--   You can use Amazon S3 event notifications to notify you when a restore
--   is initiated or completed. For more information, see <a>Configuring
--   Amazon S3 Event Notifications</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   After restoring an archived object, you can update the restoration
--   period by reissuing the request with a new period. Amazon S3 updates
--   the restoration period relative to the current time and charges only
--   for the request-there are no data transfer charges. You cannot update
--   the restoration period when Amazon S3 is actively processing your
--   current restore request for the object.
--   
--   If your bucket has a lifecycle configuration with a rule that includes
--   an expiration action, the object expiration overrides the life span
--   that you specify in a restore request. For example, if you restore an
--   object copy for 10 days, but the object is scheduled to expire in 3
--   days, Amazon S3 deletes the object in 3 days. For more information
--   about lifecycle configuration, see
--   <a>PutBucketLifecycleConfiguration</a> and <a>Object Lifecycle
--   Management</a> in <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <b>Responses</b>
--   
--   A successful action returns either the <tt>200 OK</tt> or <tt>202
--   Accepted</tt> status code.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>If the object is not previously restored, then Amazon S3 returns
--   <tt>202 Accepted</tt> in the response.</li>
--   <li>If the object is previously restored, Amazon S3 returns <tt>200
--   OK</tt> in the response.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <b>Special Errors</b>
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>- <i>Code: RestoreAlreadyInProgress</i><ul><li>/Cause: Object
--   restore is already in progress. (This error does not apply to SELECT
--   type requests.)/</li><li><i>HTTP Status Code: 409
--   Conflict</i></li><li><i>SOAP Fault Code Prefix:
--   Client</i></li></ul></li>
--   <li>- <i>Code:
--   GlacierExpeditedRetrievalNotAvailable</i><ul><li>/Cause: expedited
--   retrievals are currently not available. Try again later. (Returned if
--   there is insufficient capacity to process the Expedited request. This
--   error applies only to Expedited retrievals and not to S3 Standard or
--   Bulk retrievals.)/</li><li><i>HTTP Status Code:
--   503</i></li><li><i>SOAP Fault Code Prefix: N/A</i></li></ul></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <b>Related Resources</b>
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><a>PutBucketLifecycleConfiguration</a></li>
--   <li><a>GetBucketNotificationConfiguration</a></li>
--   <li><a>SQL Reference for Amazon S3 Select and S3 Glacier Select</a> in
--   the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i></li>
--   </ul>
module Network.AWS.S3.RestoreObject

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newRestoreObject</a> smart constructor.
data RestoreObject
RestoreObject' :: Maybe ObjectVersionId -> Maybe RequestPayer -> Maybe Text -> Maybe RestoreRequest -> BucketName -> ObjectKey -> RestoreObject

-- | VersionId used to reference a specific version of the object.
[$sel:versionId:RestoreObject'] :: RestoreObject -> Maybe ObjectVersionId
[$sel:requestPayer:RestoreObject'] :: RestoreObject -> Maybe RequestPayer

-- | The account ID of the expected bucket owner. If the bucket is owned by
--   a different account, the request will fail with an HTTP <tt>403
--   (Access Denied)</tt> error.
[$sel:expectedBucketOwner:RestoreObject'] :: RestoreObject -> Maybe Text
[$sel:restoreRequest:RestoreObject'] :: RestoreObject -> Maybe RestoreRequest

-- | The bucket name containing the object to restore.
--   
--   When using this action with an access point, you must direct requests
--   to the access point hostname. The access point hostname takes the form
--   <i>AccessPointName</i>-<i>AccountId</i>.s3-accesspoint.<i>Region</i>.amazonaws.com.
--   When using this action with an access point through the Amazon Web
--   Services SDKs, you provide the access point ARN in place of the bucket
--   name. For more information about access point ARNs, see <a>Using
--   access points</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   When using this action with Amazon S3 on Outposts, you must direct
--   requests to the S3 on Outposts hostname. The S3 on Outposts hostname
--   takes the form
--   <i>AccessPointName</i>-<i>AccountId</i>.<i>outpostID</i>.s3-outposts.<i>Region</i>.amazonaws.com.
--   When using this action using S3 on Outposts through the Amazon Web
--   Services SDKs, you provide the Outposts bucket ARN in place of the
--   bucket name. For more information about S3 on Outposts ARNs, see
--   <a>Using S3 on Outposts</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
[$sel:bucket:RestoreObject'] :: RestoreObject -> BucketName

-- | Object key for which the action was initiated.
[$sel:key:RestoreObject'] :: RestoreObject -> ObjectKey

-- | Create a value of <a>RestoreObject</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:versionId:RestoreObject'</a>, <a>restoreObject_versionId</a> -
--   VersionId used to reference a specific version of the object.
--   
--   <a>$sel:requestPayer:RestoreObject'</a>,
--   <a>restoreObject_requestPayer</a> - Undocumented member.
--   
--   <a>$sel:expectedBucketOwner:RestoreObject'</a>,
--   <a>restoreObject_expectedBucketOwner</a> - The account ID of the
--   expected bucket owner. If the bucket is owned by a different account,
--   the request will fail with an HTTP <tt>403 (Access Denied)</tt> error.
--   
--   <a>$sel:restoreRequest:RestoreObject'</a>,
--   <a>restoreObject_restoreRequest</a> - Undocumented member.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bucket:RestoreObject'</a>, <a>restoreObject_bucket</a> - The
--   bucket name containing the object to restore.
--   
--   When using this action with an access point, you must direct requests
--   to the access point hostname. The access point hostname takes the form
--   <i>AccessPointName</i>-<i>AccountId</i>.s3-accesspoint.<i>Region</i>.amazonaws.com.
--   When using this action with an access point through the Amazon Web
--   Services SDKs, you provide the access point ARN in place of the bucket
--   name. For more information about access point ARNs, see <a>Using
--   access points</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   When using this action with Amazon S3 on Outposts, you must direct
--   requests to the S3 on Outposts hostname. The S3 on Outposts hostname
--   takes the form
--   <i>AccessPointName</i>-<i>AccountId</i>.<i>outpostID</i>.s3-outposts.<i>Region</i>.amazonaws.com.
--   When using this action using S3 on Outposts through the Amazon Web
--   Services SDKs, you provide the Outposts bucket ARN in place of the
--   bucket name. For more information about S3 on Outposts ARNs, see
--   <a>Using S3 on Outposts</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:key:RestoreObject'</a>, <a>restoreObject_key</a> - Object key
--   for which the action was initiated.
newRestoreObject :: BucketName -> ObjectKey -> RestoreObject

--   a different account, the request will fail with an HTTP <tt>403
--   (Access Denied)</tt> error.
restoreObject_expectedBucketOwner :: Lens' RestoreObject (Maybe Text)

-- | The bucket name containing the object to restore.
--   
--   When using this action with an access point, you must direct requests
--   to the access point hostname. The access point hostname takes the form
--   <i>AccessPointName</i>-<i>AccountId</i>.s3-accesspoint.<i>Region</i>.amazonaws.com.
--   When using this action with an access point through the Amazon Web
--   Services SDKs, you provide the access point ARN in place of the bucket
--   name. For more information about access point ARNs, see <a>Using
--   access points</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   When using this action with Amazon S3 on Outposts, you must direct
--   requests to the S3 on Outposts hostname. The S3 on Outposts hostname
--   takes the form
--   <i>AccessPointName</i>-<i>AccountId</i>.<i>outpostID</i>.s3-outposts.<i>Region</i>.amazonaws.com.
--   When using this action using S3 on Outposts through the Amazon Web
--   Services SDKs, you provide the Outposts bucket ARN in place of the
--   bucket name. For more information about S3 on Outposts ARNs, see
--   <a>Using S3 on Outposts</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
restoreObject_bucket :: Lens' RestoreObject BucketName

-- | Creates or modifies the <tt>PublicAccessBlock</tt> configuration for
--   an Amazon S3 bucket. To use this operation, you must have the
--   <tt>s3:PutBucketPublicAccessBlock</tt> permission. For more
--   information about Amazon S3 permissions, see <a>Specifying Permissions
--   in a Policy</a>.
--   
--   When Amazon S3 evaluates the <tt>PublicAccessBlock</tt> configuration
--   for a bucket or an object, it checks the <tt>PublicAccessBlock</tt>
--   configuration for both the bucket (or the bucket that contains the
--   object) and the bucket owner's account. If the
--   <tt>PublicAccessBlock</tt> configurations are different between the
--   bucket and the account, Amazon S3 uses the most restrictive
--   combination of the bucket-level and account-level settings.
--   
--   For more information about when Amazon S3 considers a bucket or an
--   object public, see <a>The Meaning of "Public"</a>.
--   
--   <b>Related Resources</b>
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><a>GetPublicAccessBlock</a></li>
--   <li><a>DeletePublicAccessBlock</a></li>
--   <li><a>GetBucketPolicyStatus</a></li>
--   <li><a>Using Amazon S3 Block Public Access</a></li>
--   </ul>
module Network.AWS.S3.PutPublicAccessBlock

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newPutPublicAccessBlock</a> smart constructor.
data PutPublicAccessBlock
PutPublicAccessBlock' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> BucketName -> PublicAccessBlockConfiguration -> PutPublicAccessBlock

-- | The MD5 hash of the <tt>PutPublicAccessBlock</tt> request body.
--   
--   For requests made using the Amazon Web Services Command Line Interface
--   (CLI) or Amazon Web Services SDKs, this field is calculated
--   automatically.
[$sel:contentMD5:PutPublicAccessBlock'] :: PutPublicAccessBlock -> Maybe Text

-- | The account ID of the expected bucket owner. If the bucket is owned by
--   a different account, the request will fail with an HTTP <tt>403
--   (Access Denied)</tt> error.
[$sel:expectedBucketOwner:PutPublicAccessBlock'] :: PutPublicAccessBlock -> Maybe Text

-- | The name of the Amazon S3 bucket whose <tt>PublicAccessBlock</tt>
--   configuration you want to set.
[$sel:bucket:PutPublicAccessBlock'] :: PutPublicAccessBlock -> BucketName

-- | The <tt>PublicAccessBlock</tt> configuration that you want to apply to
--   this Amazon S3 bucket. You can enable the configuration options in any
--   combination. For more information about when Amazon S3 considers a
--   bucket or object public, see <a>The Meaning of "Public"</a> in the
--   <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
[$sel:publicAccessBlockConfiguration:PutPublicAccessBlock'] :: PutPublicAccessBlock -> PublicAccessBlockConfiguration

-- | Sets the supplied tag-set to an object that already exists in a
--   bucket.
--   
--   A tag is a key-value pair. You can associate tags with an object by
--   sending a PUT request against the tagging subresource that is
--   associated with the object. You can retrieve tags by sending a GET
--   request. For more information, see <a>GetObjectTagging</a>.
--   
--   For tagging-related restrictions related to characters and encodings,
--   see <a>Tag Restrictions</a>. Note that Amazon S3 limits the maximum
--   number of tags to 10 tags per object.
--   
--   To use this operation, you must have permission to perform the
--   <tt>s3:PutObjectTagging</tt> action. By default, the bucket owner has
--   this permission and can grant this permission to others.
--   
--   To put tags of any other version, use the <tt>versionId</tt> query
--   parameter. You also need permission for the
--   <tt>s3:PutObjectVersionTagging</tt> action.
--   
--   For information about the Amazon S3 object tagging feature, see
--   <a>Object Tagging</a>.
--   
--   <b>Special Errors</b>
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>- <i>Code: InvalidTagError</i><ul><li>/Cause: The tag provided was
--   not a valid tag. This error can occur if the tag did not pass input
--   validation. For more information, see <a>Object
--   Tagging</a>./</li></ul></li>
--   <li>- <i>Code: MalformedXMLError</i><ul><li><i>Cause: The XML provided
--   does not match the schema.</i></li></ul></li>
--   <li>- <i>Code: OperationAbortedError</i><ul><li>/Cause: A conflicting
--   conditional action is currently in progress against this resource.
--   Please try again./</li></ul></li>
--   <li>- <i>Code: InternalError</i><ul><li>/Cause: The service was unable
--   to apply the provided tag to the object./</li></ul></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <b>Related Resources</b>
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><a>GetObjectTagging</a></li>
--   <li><a>DeleteObjectTagging</a></li>
--   </ul>
module Network.AWS.S3.PutObjectTagging

-- | Places an Object Retention configuration on an object. For more
--   information, see <a>Locking Objects</a>. Users or accounts require the
--   <tt>s3:PutObjectRetention</tt> permission in order to place an Object
--   Retention configuration on objects. Bypassing a Governance Retention
--   configuration requires the <tt>s3:BypassGovernanceRetention</tt>
--   permission.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
--   
--   <b>Permissions</b>
--   
--   When the Object Lock retention mode is set to compliance, you need
--   <tt>s3:PutObjectRetention</tt> and
--   <tt>s3:BypassGovernanceRetention</tt> permissions. For other requests
--   to <tt>PutObjectRetention</tt>, only <tt>s3:PutObjectRetention</tt>
--   permissions are required.
module Network.AWS.S3.PutObjectRetention

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newPutObjectRetention</a> smart constructor.
data PutObjectRetention
PutObjectRetention' :: Maybe ObjectLockRetention -> Maybe ObjectVersionId -> Maybe RequestPayer -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> BucketName -> ObjectKey -> PutObjectRetention

-- | The container element for the Object Retention configuration.
[$sel:retention:PutObjectRetention'] :: PutObjectRetention -> Maybe ObjectLockRetention

-- | The version ID for the object that you want to apply this Object
--   Retention configuration to.
[$sel:versionId:PutObjectRetention'] :: PutObjectRetention -> Maybe ObjectVersionId
[$sel:requestPayer:PutObjectRetention'] :: PutObjectRetention -> Maybe RequestPayer

-- | The MD5 hash for the request body.
--   
--   For requests made using the Amazon Web Services Command Line Interface
--   (CLI) or Amazon Web Services SDKs, this field is calculated
--   automatically.
[$sel:contentMD5:PutObjectRetention'] :: PutObjectRetention -> Maybe Text

-- | Indicates whether this action should bypass Governance-mode
--   restrictions.
[$sel:bypassGovernanceRetention:PutObjectRetention'] :: PutObjectRetention -> Maybe Bool

-- | The account ID of the expected bucket owner. If the bucket is owned by
--   a different account, the request will fail with an HTTP <tt>403
--   (Access Denied)</tt> error.
[$sel:expectedBucketOwner:PutObjectRetention'] :: PutObjectRetention -> Maybe Text

-- | The bucket name that contains the object you want to apply this Object
--   Retention configuration to.
--   
--   When using this action with an access point, you must direct requests
--   to the access point hostname. The access point hostname takes the form
--   <i>AccessPointName</i>-<i>AccountId</i>.s3-accesspoint.<i>Region</i>.amazonaws.com.
--   When using this action with an access point through the Amazon Web
--   Services SDKs, you provide the access point ARN in place of the bucket
--   name. For more information about access point ARNs, see <a>Using
--   access points</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
[$sel:bucket:PutObjectRetention'] :: PutObjectRetention -> BucketName

-- | The key name for the object that you want to apply this Object
--   Retention configuration to.
[$sel:key:PutObjectRetention'] :: PutObjectRetention -> ObjectKey

-- | Create a value of <a>PutObjectRetention</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:retention:PutObjectRetention'</a>,
--   <a>putObjectRetention_retention</a> - The container element for the
--   Object Retention configuration.

--   body.

--   automatically.

--   whether this action should bypass Governance-mode restrictions.

--   expected bucket owner. If the bucket is owned by a different account,

-- | Places an Object Lock configuration on the specified bucket. The rule
--   specified in the Object Lock configuration will be applied by default
--   to every new object placed in the specified bucket. For more
--   information, see <a>Locking Objects</a>.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>The <tt>DefaultRetention</tt> settings require both a mode and a
--   period.</li>
--   <li>The <tt>DefaultRetention</tt> period can be either <tt>Days</tt>
--   or <tt>Years</tt> but you must select one. You cannot specify
--   <tt>Days</tt> and <tt>Years</tt> at the same time.</li>
--   <li>You can only enable Object Lock for new buckets. If you want to
--   turn on Object Lock for an existing bucket, contact Amazon Web
--   Services Support.</li>
--   </ul>
module Network.AWS.S3.PutObjectLockConfiguration

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newPutObjectLockConfiguration</a> smart constructor.
data PutObjectLockConfiguration
PutObjectLockConfiguration' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe ObjectLockConfiguration -> Maybe RequestPayer -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> BucketName -> PutObjectLockConfiguration

-- | A token to allow Object Lock to be enabled for an existing bucket.
[$sel:token:PutObjectLockConfiguration'] :: PutObjectLockConfiguration -> Maybe Text

-- | The Object Lock configuration that you want to apply to the specified
--   bucket.

[$sel:requestPayer:PutObjectLockConfiguration'] :: PutObjectLockConfiguration -> Maybe RequestPayer

--   
--   For requests made using the Amazon Web Services Command Line Interface
--   (CLI) or Amazon Web Services SDKs, this field is calculated
--   automatically.

--   a different account, the request will fail with an HTTP <tt>403
--   (Access Denied)</tt> error.

--   replace.

-- | Uses the <tt>acl</tt> subresource to set the access control list (ACL)
--   permissions for a new or existing object in an S3 bucket. You must
--   have <tt>WRITE_ACP</tt> permission to set the ACL of an object. For
--   more information, see <a>What permissions can I grant?</a> in the
--   <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
--   
--   Depending on your application needs, you can choose to set the ACL on
--   an object using either the request body or the headers. For example,
--   if you have an existing application that updates a bucket ACL using
--   the request body, you can continue to use that approach. For more
--   information, see <a>Access Control List (ACL) Overview</a> in the
--   <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <b>Access Permissions</b>
--   
--   You can set access permissions using one of the following methods:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Specify a canned ACL with the <tt>x-amz-acl</tt> request header.
--   Amazon S3 supports a set of predefined ACLs, known as canned ACLs.
--   Each canned ACL has a predefined set of grantees and permissions.
--   Specify the canned ACL name as the value of <tt>x-amz-ac</tt>l. If you
--   use this header, you cannot use other access control-specific headers
--   in your request. For more information, see <a>Canned ACL</a>.</li>
--   <li>Specify access permissions explicitly with the
--   <tt>x-amz-grant-read</tt>, <tt>x-amz-grant-read-acp</tt>,
--   <tt>x-amz-grant-write-acp</tt>, and <tt>x-amz-grant-full-control</tt>
--   headers. When using these headers, you specify explicit access
--   permissions and grantees (Amazon Web Services accounts or Amazon S3
--   groups) who will receive the permission. If you use these ACL-specific
--   headers, you cannot use <tt>x-amz-acl</tt> header to set a canned ACL.
--   These parameters map to the set of permissions that Amazon S3 supports
--   in an ACL. For more information, see <a>Access Control List (ACL)
--   Overview</a>.You specify each grantee as a type=value pair, where the
--   type is one of the following:<ul><li><tt>id</tt> – if the value
--   specified is the canonical user ID of an Amazon Web Services
--   account</li><li><tt>uri</tt> – if you are granting permissions to a
--   predefined group</li><li><tt>emailAddress</tt> – if the value
--   specified is the email address of an Amazon Web Services accountUsing
--   email addresses to specify a grantee is only supported in the
--   following Amazon Web Services Regions:<ul><li>US East (N.
--   Virginia)</li><li>US West (N. California)</li><li>US West
--   (Oregon)</li><li>Asia Pacific (Singapore)</li><li>Asia Pacific
--   (Sydney)</li><li>Asia Pacific (Tokyo)</li><li>Europe
--   (Ireland)</li><li>South America (São Paulo)</li></ul>For a list of all
--   the Amazon S3 supported Regions and endpoints, see <a>Regions and
--   Endpoints</a> in the Amazon Web Services General
--   Reference.</li></ul>For example, the following
--   <tt>x-amz-grant-read</tt> header grants list objects permission to the
--   two Amazon Web Services accounts identified by their email
--   addresses.<pre>x-amz-grant-read: emailAddress="xyz@amazon.com",
--   emailAddress="abc@amazon.com"</pre></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   You can use either a canned ACL or specify access permissions
--   explicitly. You cannot do both.
--   
--   <b>Grantee Values</b>
--   
--   You can specify the person (grantee) to whom you're assigning access
--   rights (using request elements) in the following ways:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>By the person's ID:<pre>&lt;Grantee
--   xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
--   xsi:type="CanonicalUser"&gt;&lt;ID&gt;&lt;&gt;ID&lt;&gt;&lt;/ID&gt;&lt;DisplayName&gt;&lt;&gt;GranteesEmail&lt;&gt;&lt;/DisplayName&gt;
--   &lt;/Grantee&gt;</pre>DisplayName is optional and ignored in the
--   request.</li>
--   <li>By URI:<pre>&lt;Grantee
--   xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
--   xsi:type="Group"&gt;&lt;URI&gt;&lt;&gt;http://acs.amazonaws.com/groups/global/AuthenticatedUsers&lt;&gt;&lt;/URI&gt;&lt;/Grantee&gt;</pre></li>
--   <li>By Email address:<pre>&lt;Grantee
--   xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
--   xsi:type="AmazonCustomerByEmail"&gt;&lt;EmailAddress&gt;&lt;&gt;Grantees@email.com&lt;&gt;&lt;/EmailAddress&gt;lt;/Grantee&gt;</pre>The
--   grantee is resolved to the CanonicalUser and, in a response to a GET
--   Object acl request, appears as the CanonicalUser.Using email addresses
--   to specify a grantee is only supported in the following Amazon Web
--   Services Regions:<ul><li>US East (N. Virginia)</li><li>US West (N.
--   California)</li><li>US West (Oregon)</li><li>Asia Pacific
--   (Singapore)</li><li>Asia Pacific (Sydney)</li><li>Asia Pacific
--   (Tokyo)</li><li>Europe (Ireland)</li><li>South America (São
--   Paulo)</li></ul>For a list of all the Amazon S3 supported Regions and
--   endpoints, see <a>Regions and Endpoints</a> in the Amazon Web Services
--   General Reference.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <b>Versioning</b>
--   
--   The ACL of an object is set at the object version level. By default,
--   PUT sets the ACL of the current version of an object. To set the ACL
--   of a different version, use the <tt>versionId</tt> subresource.
--   
--   <b>Related Resources</b>
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><a>CopyObject</a></li>
--   <li><a>GetObject</a></li>
--   </ul>
module Network.AWS.S3.PutObjectAcl

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newPutObjectAcl</a> smart constructor.
data PutObjectAcl
PutObjectAcl' :: Maybe ObjectVersionId -> Maybe Text -> Maybe RequestPayer -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe AccessControlPolicy -> Maybe Text -> Maybe ObjectCannedACL -> Maybe Text -> BucketName -> ObjectKey -> PutObjectAcl

-- | VersionId used to reference a specific version of the object.
[$sel:versionId:PutObjectAcl'] :: PutObjectAcl -> Maybe ObjectVersionId

-- | Allows grantee to read the bucket ACL.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
[$sel:grantReadACP:PutObjectAcl'] :: PutObjectAcl -> Maybe Text
[$sel:requestPayer:PutObjectAcl'] :: PutObjectAcl -> Maybe RequestPayer

-- | Allows grantee to write the ACL for the applicable bucket.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
[$sel:grantWriteACP:PutObjectAcl'] :: PutObjectAcl -> Maybe Text

-- | Allows grantee to list the objects in the bucket.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
[$sel:grantRead:PutObjectAcl'] :: PutObjectAcl -> Maybe Text

-- | Allows grantee the read, write, read ACP, and write ACP permissions on
--   the bucket.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
[$sel:grantFullControl:PutObjectAcl'] :: PutObjectAcl -> Maybe Text

-- | The base64-encoded 128-bit MD5 digest of the data. This header must be
--   used as a message integrity check to verify that the request body was
--   not corrupted in transit. For more information, go to <a>RFC
--   1864.</a>&gt;
--   
--   For requests made using the Amazon Web Services Command Line Interface
--   (CLI) or Amazon Web Services SDKs, this field is calculated
--   automatically.
[$sel:contentMD5:PutObjectAcl'] :: PutObjectAcl -> Maybe Text

-- | Contains the elements that set the ACL permissions for an object per
--   grantee.
[$sel:accessControlPolicy:PutObjectAcl'] :: PutObjectAcl -> Maybe AccessControlPolicy

-- | Allows grantee to create new objects in the bucket.
--   
--   For the bucket and object owners of existing objects, also allows
--   deletions and overwrites of those objects.
[$sel:grantWrite:PutObjectAcl'] :: PutObjectAcl -> Maybe Text

-- | The canned ACL to apply to the object. For more information, see
--   <a>Canned ACL</a>.
[$sel:acl:PutObjectAcl'] :: PutObjectAcl -> Maybe ObjectCannedACL

-- | The account ID of the expected bucket owner. If the bucket is owned by
--   a different account, the request will fail with an HTTP <tt>403
--   (Access Denied)</tt> error.
[$sel:expectedBucketOwner:PutObjectAcl'] :: PutObjectAcl -> Maybe Text

-- | The bucket name that contains the object to which you want to attach
--   the ACL.
--   
--   When using this action with an access point, you must direct requests
--   to the access point hostname. The access point hostname takes the form
--   <i>AccessPointName</i>-<i>AccountId</i>.s3-accesspoint.<i>Region</i>.amazonaws.com.
--   When using this action with an access point through the Amazon Web
--   Services SDKs, you provide the access point ARN in place of the bucket
--   name. For more information about access point ARNs, see <a>Using
--   access points</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
[$sel:bucket:PutObjectAcl'] :: PutObjectAcl -> BucketName

-- | Key for which the PUT action was initiated.
--   
--   When using this action with an access point, you must direct requests
--   to the access point hostname. The access point hostname takes the form
--   <i>AccessPointName</i>-<i>AccountId</i>.s3-accesspoint.<i>Region</i>.amazonaws.com.
--   When using this action with an access point through the Amazon Web
--   Services SDKs, you provide the access point ARN in place of the bucket
--   name. For more information about access point ARNs, see <a>Using
--   access points</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   When using this action with Amazon S3 on Outposts, you must direct
--   requests to the S3 on Outposts hostname. The S3 on Outposts hostname
--   takes the form
--   <i>AccessPointName</i>-<i>AccountId</i>.<i>outpostID</i>.s3-outposts.<i>Region</i>.amazonaws.com.
--   When using this action using S3 on Outposts through the Amazon Web
--   Services SDKs, you provide the Outposts bucket ARN in place of the
--   bucket name. For more information about S3 on Outposts ARNs, see
--   <a>Using S3 on Outposts</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
[$sel:key:PutObjectAcl'] :: PutObjectAcl -> ObjectKey
