-- | Adds an object to a bucket. You must have WRITE permissions on a
--   bucket to add an object to it.
--   
--   Amazon S3 never adds partial objects; if you receive a success
--   response, Amazon S3 added the entire object to the bucket.
--   
--   Amazon S3 is a distributed system. If it receives multiple write
--   requests for the same object simultaneously, it overwrites all but the
--   last object written. Amazon S3 does not provide object locking; if you
--   need this, make sure to build it into your application layer or use
--   versioning instead.
--   
--   To ensure that data is not corrupted traversing the network, use the
--   <tt>Content-MD5</tt> header. When you use this header, Amazon S3
--   checks the object against the provided MD5 value and, if they do not
--   match, returns an error. Additionally, you can calculate the MD5 while
--   putting an object to Amazon S3 and compare the returned ETag to the
--   calculated MD5 value.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>To successfully complete the <tt>PutObject</tt> request, you must
--   have the <tt>s3:PutObject</tt> in your IAM permissions.</li>
--   <li>To successfully change the objects acl of your <tt>PutObject</tt>
--   request, you must have the <tt>s3:PutObjectAcl</tt> in your IAM
--   permissions.</li>
--   <li>The <tt>Content-MD5</tt> header is required for any request to
--   upload an object with a retention period configured using Amazon S3
--   Object Lock. For more information about Amazon S3 Object Lock, see
--   <a>Amazon S3 Object Lock Overview</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User
--   Guide</i>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <b>Server-side Encryption</b>
--   
--   You can optionally request server-side encryption. With server-side
--   encryption, Amazon S3 encrypts your data as it writes it to disks in
--   its data centers and decrypts the data when you access it. You have
--   the option to provide your own encryption key or use Amazon Web
--   Services managed encryption keys (SSE-S3 or SSE-KMS). For more
--   information, see <a>Using Server-Side Encryption</a>.
--   
--   If you request server-side encryption using Amazon Web Services Key
--   Management Service (SSE-KMS), you can enable an S3 Bucket Key at the
--   object-level. For more information, see <a>Amazon S3 Bucket Keys</a>
--   in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <b>Access Control List (ACL)-Specific Request Headers</b>
--   
--   You can use headers to grant ACL- based permissions. By default, all
--   objects are private. Only the owner has full access control. When
--   adding a new object, you can grant permissions to individual Amazon
--   Web Services accounts or to predefined groups defined by Amazon S3.
--   These permissions are then added to the ACL on the object. For more
--   information, see <a>Access Control List (ACL) Overview</a> and
--   <a>Managing ACLs Using the REST API</a>.
--   
--   <b>Storage Class Options</b>
--   
--   By default, Amazon S3 uses the STANDARD Storage Class to store newly
--   created objects. The STANDARD storage class provides high durability
--   and high availability. Depending on performance needs, you can specify
--   a different Storage Class. Amazon S3 on Outposts only uses the
--   OUTPOSTS Storage Class. For more information, see <a>Storage
--   Classes</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <b>Versioning</b>
--   
--   If you enable versioning for a bucket, Amazon S3 automatically
--   generates a unique version ID for the object being stored. Amazon S3
--   returns this ID in the response. When you enable versioning for a
--   bucket, if Amazon S3 receives multiple write requests for the same
--   object simultaneously, it stores all of the objects.
--   
--   For more information about versioning, see <a>Adding Objects to
--   Versioning Enabled Buckets</a>. For information about returning the
--   versioning state of a bucket, see <a>GetBucketVersioning</a>.
--   
--   <b>Related Resources</b>
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><a>CopyObject</a></li>
--   <li><a>DeleteObject</a></li>
--   </ul>
module Network.AWS.S3.PutObject

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newPutObject</a> smart constructor.
data PutObject
PutObject' :: Maybe Integer -> Maybe ObjectLockMode -> Maybe ISO8601 -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe (Sensitive Text) -> Maybe RequestPayer -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe StorageClass -> Maybe Text -> Maybe (Sensitive Text) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe ISO8601 -> HashMap Text Text -> Maybe (Sensitive Text) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe ObjectLockLegalHoldStatus -> Maybe ObjectCannedACL -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe ServerSideEncryption -> Maybe Text -> BucketName -> ObjectKey -> RequestBody -> PutObject

-- | Size of the body in bytes. This parameter is useful when the size of
--   the body cannot be determined automatically. For more information, see
--   <a>http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.13</a>.
[$sel:contentLength:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> Maybe Integer

-- | The Object Lock mode that you want to apply to this object.
[$sel:objectLockMode:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> Maybe ObjectLockMode

-- | The date and time at which the object is no longer cacheable. For more
--   information, see
--   <a>http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.21</a>.
[$sel:expires:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> Maybe ISO8601

-- | Allows grantee to read the object ACL.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
[$sel:grantReadACP:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> Maybe Text

-- | Specifies the algorithm to use to when encrypting the object (for
--   example, AES256).
[$sel:sSECustomerAlgorithm:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> Maybe Text

-- | Specifies the customer-provided encryption key for Amazon S3 to use in
--   encrypting data. This value is used to store the object and then it is
--   discarded; Amazon S3 does not store the encryption key. The key must
--   be appropriate for use with the algorithm specified in the
--   <tt>x-amz-server-side-encryption-customer-algorithm</tt> header.
[$sel:sSECustomerKey:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> Maybe (Sensitive Text)
[$sel:requestPayer:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> Maybe RequestPayer

-- | Allows grantee to write the ACL for the applicable object.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
[$sel:grantWriteACP:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> Maybe Text

-- | Specifies whether Amazon S3 should use an S3 Bucket Key for object
--   encryption with server-side encryption using AWS KMS (SSE-KMS).
--   Setting this header to <tt>true</tt> causes Amazon S3 to use an S3
--   Bucket Key for object encryption with SSE-KMS.
--   
--   Specifying this header with a PUT action doesn’t affect bucket-level
--   settings for S3 Bucket Key.
[$sel:bucketKeyEnabled:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> Maybe Bool

-- | If the bucket is configured as a website, redirects requests for this
--   object to another object in the same bucket or to an external URL.
--   Amazon S3 stores the value of this header in the object metadata. For
--   information about object metadata, see <a>Object Key and Metadata</a>.
--   
--   In the following example, the request header sets the redirect to an
--   object (anotherPage.html) in the same bucket:
--   
--   <pre>
--   x-amz-website-redirect-location: /anotherPage.html
--   </pre>
--   
--   In the following example, the request header sets the object redirect
--   to another website:
--   
--   <pre>
--   x-amz-website-redirect-location: http://www.example.com/
--   </pre>
--   
--   For more information about website hosting in Amazon S3, see
--   <a>Hosting Websites on Amazon S3</a> and <a>How to Configure Website
--   Page Redirects</a>.
[$sel:websiteRedirectLocation:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> Maybe Text

-- | Allows grantee to read the object data and its metadata.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
[$sel:grantRead:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> Maybe Text

-- | By default, Amazon S3 uses the STANDARD Storage Class to store newly
--   created objects. The STANDARD storage class provides high durability
--   and high availability. Depending on performance needs, you can specify
--   a different Storage Class. Amazon S3 on Outposts only uses the
--   OUTPOSTS Storage Class. For more information, see <a>Storage
--   Classes</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
[$sel:storageClass:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> Maybe StorageClass

-- | Specifies the 128-bit MD5 digest of the encryption key according to
--   RFC 1321. Amazon S3 uses this header for a message integrity check to
--   ensure that the encryption key was transmitted without error.
[$sel:sSECustomerKeyMD5:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> Maybe Text

-- | If <tt>x-amz-server-side-encryption</tt> is present and has the value
--   of <tt>aws:kms</tt>, this header specifies the ID of the Amazon Web
--   Services Key Management Service (Amazon Web Services KMS) symmetrical
--   customer managed key that was used for the object. If you specify
--   <tt>x-amz-server-side-encryption:aws:kms</tt>, but do not provide<tt>
--   x-amz-server-side-encryption-aws-kms-key-id</tt>, Amazon S3 uses the
--   Amazon Web Services managed key to protect the data. If the KMS key
--   does not exist in the same account issuing the command, you must use
--   the full ARN and not just the ID.
[$sel:sSEKMSKeyId:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> Maybe (Sensitive Text)

-- | Gives the grantee READ, READ_ACP, and WRITE_ACP permissions on the
--   object.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
[$sel:grantFullControl:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> Maybe Text

-- | Specifies what content encodings have been applied to the object and
--   thus what decoding mechanisms must be applied to obtain the media-type
--   referenced by the Content-Type header field. For more information, see
--   <a>http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.11</a>.
[$sel:contentEncoding:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> Maybe Text

-- | The tag-set for the object. The tag-set must be encoded as URL Query
--   parameters. (For example, "Key1=Value1")
[$sel:tagging:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> Maybe Text

-- | The base64-encoded 128-bit MD5 digest of the message (without the
--   headers) according to RFC 1864. This header can be used as a message
--   integrity check to verify that the data is the same data that was
--   originally sent. Although it is optional, we recommend using the
--   Content-MD5 mechanism as an end-to-end integrity check. For more
--   information about REST request authentication, see <a>REST
--   Authentication</a>.
[$sel:contentMD5:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> Maybe Text

-- | The date and time when you want this object's Object Lock to expire.
--   Must be formatted as a timestamp parameter.
[$sel:objectLockRetainUntilDate:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> Maybe ISO8601

-- | A map of metadata to store with the object in S3.
[$sel:metadata:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> HashMap Text Text

-- | Specifies the Amazon Web Services KMS Encryption Context to use for
--   object encryption. The value of this header is a base64-encoded UTF-8
--   string holding JSON with the encryption context key-value pairs.
[$sel:sSEKMSEncryptionContext:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> Maybe (Sensitive Text)

-- | Can be used to specify caching behavior along the request/reply chain.
--   For more information, see
--   <a>http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.9</a>.
[$sel:cacheControl:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> Maybe Text

-- | The language the content is in.
[$sel:contentLanguage:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> Maybe Text

-- | Specifies whether a legal hold will be applied to this object. For
--   more information about S3 Object Lock, see <a>Object Lock</a>.
[$sel:objectLockLegalHoldStatus:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> Maybe ObjectLockLegalHoldStatus

-- | The canned ACL to apply to the object. For more information, see
--   <a>Canned ACL</a>.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
[$sel:acl:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> Maybe ObjectCannedACL

-- | Specifies presentational information for the object. For more
--   information, see
--   <a>http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec19.html#sec19.5.1</a>.
[$sel:contentDisposition:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> Maybe Text

-- | The account ID of the expected bucket owner. If the bucket is owned by
--   a different account, the request will fail with an HTTP <tt>403
--   (Access Denied)</tt> error.
[$sel:expectedBucketOwner:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> Maybe Text

-- | The server-side encryption algorithm used when storing this object in
--   Amazon S3 (for example, AES256, aws:kms).
[$sel:serverSideEncryption:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> Maybe ServerSideEncryption

-- | A standard MIME type describing the format of the contents. For more
--   information, see
--   <a>http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.17</a>.
[$sel:contentType:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> Maybe Text

-- | The bucket name to which the PUT action was initiated.
--   
--   When using this action with an access point, you must direct requests
--   to the access point hostname. The access point hostname takes the form
--   <i>AccessPointName</i>-<i>AccountId</i>.s3-accesspoint.<i>Region</i>.amazonaws.com.
--   When using this action with an access point through the Amazon Web
--   Services SDKs, you provide the access point ARN in place of the bucket
--   name. For more information about access point ARNs, see <a>Using
--   access points</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   When using this action with Amazon S3 on Outposts, you must direct
--   requests to the S3 on Outposts hostname. The S3 on Outposts hostname
--   takes the form
--   <i>AccessPointName</i>-<i>AccountId</i>.<i>outpostID</i>.s3-outposts.<i>Region</i>.amazonaws.com.
--   When using this action using S3 on Outposts through the Amazon Web
--   Services SDKs, you provide the Outposts bucket ARN in place of the
--   bucket name. For more information about S3 on Outposts ARNs, see
--   <a>Using S3 on Outposts</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
[$sel:bucket:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> BucketName

-- | Object key for which the PUT action was initiated.
[$sel:key:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> ObjectKey

-- | Object data.
[$sel:body:PutObject'] :: PutObject -> RequestBody

-- | Create a value of <a>PutObject</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:contentLength:PutObject'</a>, <a>putObject_contentLength</a> -
--   Size of the body in bytes. This parameter is useful when the size of
--   the body cannot be determined automatically. For more information, see
--   <a>http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.13</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:objectLockMode:PutObject'</a>, <a>putObject_objectLockMode</a>
--   - The Object Lock mode that you want to apply to this object.
--   
--   <a>$sel:expires:PutObject'</a>, <a>putObject_expires</a> - The date
--   and time at which the object is no longer cacheable. For more
--   information, see
--   <a>http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.21</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:grantReadACP:PutObject'</a>, <a>putObject_grantReadACP</a> -
--   Allows grantee to read the object ACL.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sSECustomerAlgorithm:PutObject'</a>,
--   <a>putObject_sSECustomerAlgorithm</a> - Specifies the algorithm to use
--   to when encrypting the object (for example, AES256).
--   
--   <a>$sel:sSECustomerKey:PutObject'</a>, <a>putObject_sSECustomerKey</a>
--   - Specifies the customer-provided encryption key for Amazon S3 to use
--   in encrypting data. This value is used to store the object and then it
--   is discarded; Amazon S3 does not store the encryption key. The key
--   must be appropriate for use with the algorithm specified in the
--   <tt>x-amz-server-side-encryption-customer-algorithm</tt> header.
--   
--   <a>$sel:requestPayer:PutObject'</a>, <a>putObject_requestPayer</a> -
--   Undocumented member.
--   
--   <a>$sel:grantWriteACP:PutObject'</a>, <a>putObject_grantWriteACP</a> -
--   Allows grantee to write the ACL for the applicable object.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bucketKeyEnabled:PutObject'</a>,
--   <a>putObject_bucketKeyEnabled</a> - Specifies whether Amazon S3 should
--   use an S3 Bucket Key for object encryption with server-side encryption
--   using AWS KMS (SSE-KMS). Setting this header to <tt>true</tt> causes
--   Amazon S3 to use an S3 Bucket Key for object encryption with SSE-KMS.
--   
--   Specifying this header with a PUT action doesn’t affect bucket-level
--   settings for S3 Bucket Key.
--   
--   <a>$sel:websiteRedirectLocation:PutObject'</a>,
--   <a>putObject_websiteRedirectLocation</a> - If the bucket is configured
--   as a website, redirects requests for this object to another object in
--   the same bucket or to an external URL. Amazon S3 stores the value of
--   this header in the object metadata. For information about object
--   metadata, see <a>Object Key and Metadata</a>.
--   
--   In the following example, the request header sets the redirect to an
--   object (anotherPage.html) in the same bucket:
--   
--   <pre>
--   x-amz-website-redirect-location: /anotherPage.html
--   </pre>
--   
--   In the following example, the request header sets the object redirect
--   to another website:
--   
--   <pre>
--   x-amz-website-redirect-location: http://www.example.com/
--   </pre>
--   
--   For more information about website hosting in Amazon S3, see
--   <a>Hosting Websites on Amazon S3</a> and <a>How to Configure Website
--   Page Redirects</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:grantRead:PutObject'</a>, <a>putObject_grantRead</a> - Allows
--   grantee to read the object data and its metadata.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
--   
--   <a>$sel:storageClass:PutObject'</a>, <a>putObject_storageClass</a> -
--   By default, Amazon S3 uses the STANDARD Storage Class to store newly
--   created objects. The STANDARD storage class provides high durability
--   and high availability. Depending on performance needs, you can specify
--   a different Storage Class. Amazon S3 on Outposts only uses the
--   OUTPOSTS Storage Class. For more information, see <a>Storage
--   Classes</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sSECustomerKeyMD5:PutObject'</a>,
--   <a>putObject_sSECustomerKeyMD5</a> - Specifies the 128-bit MD5 digest
--   of the encryption key according to RFC 1321. Amazon S3 uses this
--   header for a message integrity check to ensure that the encryption key
--   was transmitted without error.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sSEKMSKeyId:PutObject'</a>, <a>putObject_sSEKMSKeyId</a> - If
--   <tt>x-amz-server-side-encryption</tt> is present and has the value of
--   <tt>aws:kms</tt>, this header specifies the ID of the Amazon Web
--   Services Key Management Service (Amazon Web Services KMS) symmetrical
--   customer managed key that was used for the object. If you specify
--   <tt>x-amz-server-side-encryption:aws:kms</tt>, but do not provide<tt>
--   x-amz-server-side-encryption-aws-kms-key-id</tt>, Amazon S3 uses the
--   Amazon Web Services managed key to protect the data. If the KMS key
--   does not exist in the same account issuing the command, you must use
--   the full ARN and not just the ID.
--   
--   <a>$sel:grantFullControl:PutObject'</a>,
--   <a>putObject_grantFullControl</a> - Gives the grantee READ, READ_ACP,
--   and WRITE_ACP permissions on the object.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
--   
--   <a>$sel:contentEncoding:PutObject'</a>,
--   <a>putObject_contentEncoding</a> - Specifies what content encodings
--   have been applied to the object and thus what decoding mechanisms must
--   be applied to obtain the media-type referenced by the Content-Type
--   header field. For more information, see
--   <a>http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.11</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tagging:PutObject'</a>, <a>putObject_tagging</a> - The tag-set
--   for the object. The tag-set must be encoded as URL Query parameters.
--   (For example, "Key1=Value1")
--   
--   <a>$sel:contentMD5:PutObject'</a>, <a>putObject_contentMD5</a> - The
--   base64-encoded 128-bit MD5 digest of the message (without the headers)
--   according to RFC 1864. This header can be used as a message integrity
--   check to verify that the data is the same data that was originally
--   sent. Although it is optional, we recommend using the Content-MD5
--   mechanism as an end-to-end integrity check. For more information about
--   REST request authentication, see <a>REST Authentication</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:objectLockRetainUntilDate:PutObject'</a>,
--   <a>putObject_objectLockRetainUntilDate</a> - The date and time when
--   you want this object's Object Lock to expire. Must be formatted as a
--   timestamp parameter.
--   
--   <a>$sel:metadata:PutObject'</a>, <a>putObject_metadata</a> - A map of
--   metadata to store with the object in S3.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sSEKMSEncryptionContext:PutObject'</a>,
--   <a>putObject_sSEKMSEncryptionContext</a> - Specifies the Amazon Web
--   Services KMS Encryption Context to use for object encryption. The
--   value of this header is a base64-encoded UTF-8 string holding JSON
--   with the encryption context key-value pairs.
--   
--   <a>$sel:cacheControl:PutObject'</a>, <a>putObject_cacheControl</a> -
--   Can be used to specify caching behavior along the request/reply chain.
--   For more information, see
--   <a>http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.9</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:contentLanguage:PutObject'</a>,
--   <a>putObject_contentLanguage</a> - The language the content is in.
--   
--   <a>$sel:objectLockLegalHoldStatus:PutObject'</a>,
--   <a>putObject_objectLockLegalHoldStatus</a> - Specifies whether a legal
--   hold will be applied to this object. For more information about S3
--   Object Lock, see <a>Object Lock</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:acl:PutObject'</a>, <a>putObject_acl</a> - The canned ACL to
--   apply to the object. For more information, see <a>Canned ACL</a>.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
--   
--   <a>$sel:contentDisposition:PutObject'</a>,
--   <a>putObject_contentDisposition</a> - Specifies presentational
--   information for the object. For more information, see
--   <a>http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec19.html#sec19.5.1</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:expectedBucketOwner:PutObject'</a>,
--   <a>putObject_expectedBucketOwner</a> - The account ID of the expected
--   bucket owner. If the bucket is owned by a different account, the
--   request will fail with an HTTP <tt>403 (Access Denied)</tt> error.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serverSideEncryption:PutObject'</a>,
--   <a>putObject_serverSideEncryption</a> - The server-side encryption
--   algorithm used when storing this object in Amazon S3 (for example,
--   AES256, aws:kms).
--   
--   <a>$sel:contentType:PutObject'</a>, <a>putObject_contentType</a> - A
--   standard MIME type describing the format of the contents. For more
--   information, see
--   <a>http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.17</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bucket:PutObject'</a>, <a>putObject_bucket</a> - The bucket
--   name to which the PUT action was initiated.
--   
--   When using this action with an access point, you must direct requests
--   to the access point hostname. The access point hostname takes the form
--   <i>AccessPointName</i>-<i>AccountId</i>.s3-accesspoint.<i>Region</i>.amazonaws.com.
--   When using this action with an access point through the Amazon Web
--   Services SDKs, you provide the access point ARN in place of the bucket
--   name. For more information about access point ARNs, see <a>Using
--   access points</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   When using this action with Amazon S3 on Outposts, you must direct
--   requests to the S3 on Outposts hostname. The S3 on Outposts hostname
--   takes the form
--   <i>AccessPointName</i>-<i>AccountId</i>.<i>outpostID</i>.s3-outposts.<i>Region</i>.amazonaws.com.
--   When using this action using S3 on Outposts through the Amazon Web
--   Services SDKs, you provide the Outposts bucket ARN in place of the
--   bucket name. For more information about S3 on Outposts ARNs, see
--   <a>Using S3 on Outposts</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:key:PutObject'</a>, <a>putObject_key</a> - Object key for
--   which the PUT action was initiated.
--   
--   <a>$sel:body:PutObject'</a>, <a>putObject_body</a> - Object data.
newPutObject :: BucketName -> ObjectKey -> RequestBody -> PutObject

-- | Size of the body in bytes. This parameter is useful when the size of
--   the body cannot be determined automatically. For more information, see
--   <a>http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.13</a>.
putObject_contentLength :: Lens' PutObject (Maybe Integer)

-- | The Object Lock mode that you want to apply to this object.
putObject_objectLockMode :: Lens' PutObject (Maybe ObjectLockMode)

-- | The date and time at which the object is no longer cacheable. For more
--   information, see
--   <a>http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.21</a>.
putObject_expires :: Lens' PutObject (Maybe UTCTime)

-- | Allows grantee to read the object ACL.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
putObject_grantReadACP :: Lens' PutObject (Maybe Text)

-- | Specifies the algorithm to use to when encrypting the object (for
--   example, AES256).
putObject_sSECustomerAlgorithm :: Lens' PutObject (Maybe Text)

-- | Specifies the customer-provided encryption key for Amazon S3 to use in
--   encrypting data. This value is used to store the object and then it is
--   discarded; Amazon S3 does not store the encryption key. The key must
--   be appropriate for use with the algorithm specified in the
--   <tt>x-amz-server-side-encryption-customer-algorithm</tt> header.
putObject_sSECustomerKey :: Lens' PutObject (Maybe Text)

-- | Undocumented member.
putObject_requestPayer :: Lens' PutObject (Maybe RequestPayer)

-- | Allows grantee to write the ACL for the applicable object.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
putObject_grantWriteACP :: Lens' PutObject (Maybe Text)

-- | Specifies whether Amazon S3 should use an S3 Bucket Key for object
--   encryption with server-side encryption using AWS KMS (SSE-KMS).
--   Setting this header to <tt>true</tt> causes Amazon S3 to use an S3
--   Bucket Key for object encryption with SSE-KMS.
--   
--   Specifying this header with a PUT action doesn’t affect bucket-level
--   settings for S3 Bucket Key.
putObject_bucketKeyEnabled :: Lens' PutObject (Maybe Bool)

-- | If the bucket is configured as a website, redirects requests for this
--   object to another object in the same bucket or to an external URL.
--   Amazon S3 stores the value of this header in the object metadata. For
--   information about object metadata, see <a>Object Key and Metadata</a>.
--

--   object (anotherPage.html) in the same bucket:
--   
--   <pre>

--   </pre>

--   to another website:
--   
--   <pre>
--   x-amz-website-redirect-location: http://www.example.com/
--   </pre>
--   
--   For more information about website hosting in Amazon S3, see
--   <a>Hosting Websites on Amazon S3</a> and <a>How to Configure Website
--   Page Redirects</a>.
putObject_websiteRedirectLocation :: Lens' PutObject (Maybe Text)

-- | Allows grantee to read the object data and its metadata.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
putObject_grantRead :: Lens' PutObject (Maybe Text)

-- | By default, Amazon S3 uses the STANDARD Storage Class to store newly
--   created objects. The STANDARD storage class provides high durability
--   and high availability. Depending on performance needs, you can specify
--   a different Storage Class. Amazon S3 on Outposts only uses the
--   OUTPOSTS Storage Class. For more information, see <a>Storage
--   Classes</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
putObject_storageClass :: Lens' PutObject (Maybe StorageClass)

-- | Specifies the 128-bit MD5 digest of the encryption key according to
--   RFC 1321. Amazon S3 uses this header for a message integrity check to
--   ensure that the encryption key was transmitted without error.
putObject_sSECustomerKeyMD5 :: Lens' PutObject (Maybe Text)

-- | If <tt>x-amz-server-side-encryption</tt> is present and has the value
--   of <tt>aws:kms</tt>, this header specifies the ID of the Amazon Web
--   Services Key Management Service (Amazon Web Services KMS) symmetrical

--   object.
--

putObject_grantFullControl :: Lens' PutObject (Maybe Text)

-- | Specifies what content encodings have been applied to the object and
--   thus what decoding mechanisms must be applied to obtain the media-type

putObject_contentEncoding :: Lens' PutObject (Maybe Text)

putObject_tagging :: Lens' PutObject (Maybe Text)

--   Content-MD5 mechanism as an end-to-end integrity check. For more

--   Authentication</a>.
putObject_contentMD5 :: Lens' PutObject (Maybe Text)

-- | The date and time when you want this object's Object Lock to expire.
--   Must be formatted as a timestamp parameter.
putObject_objectLockRetainUntilDate :: Lens' PutObject (Maybe UTCTime)

-- | A map of metadata to store with the object in S3.
putObject_metadata :: Lens' PutObject (HashMap Text Text)

-- | Specifies the Amazon Web Services KMS Encryption Context to use for
--   object encryption. The value of this header is a base64-encoded UTF-8
--   string holding JSON with the encryption context key-value pairs.
putObject_sSEKMSEncryptionContext :: Lens' PutObject (Maybe Text)

-- | Can be used to specify caching behavior along the request/reply chain.
--   For more information, see
--   <a>http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.9</a>.
putObject_cacheControl :: Lens' PutObject (Maybe Text)

putObject_contentLanguage :: Lens' PutObject (Maybe Text)

--   more information about S3 Object Lock, see <a>Object Lock</a>.
putObject_objectLockLegalHoldStatus :: Lens' PutObject (Maybe ObjectLockLegalHoldStatus)

-- | The canned ACL to apply to the object. For more information, see
--   <a>Canned ACL</a>.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
putObject_acl :: Lens' PutObject (Maybe ObjectCannedACL)

-- | Specifies presentational information for the object. For more
--   information, see
--   <a>http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec19.html#sec19.5.1</a>.
putObject_contentDisposition :: Lens' PutObject (Maybe Text)

-- | The account ID of the expected bucket owner. If the bucket is owned by
--   a different account, the request will fail with an HTTP <tt>403
--   (Access Denied)</tt> error.
putObject_expectedBucketOwner :: Lens' PutObject (Maybe Text)

-- | The server-side encryption algorithm used when storing this object in
--   Amazon S3 (for example, AES256, aws:kms).
putObject_serverSideEncryption :: Lens' PutObject (Maybe ServerSideEncryption)

-- | A standard MIME type describing the format of the contents. For more
--   information, see
--   <a>http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.17</a>.
putObject_contentType :: Lens' PutObject (Maybe Text)

-- | The bucket name to which the PUT action was initiated.
--   
--   When using this action with an access point, you must direct requests
--   to the access point hostname. The access point hostname takes the form
--   <i>AccessPointName</i>-<i>AccountId</i>.s3-accesspoint.<i>Region</i>.amazonaws.com.
--   When using this action with an access point through the Amazon Web
--   Services SDKs, you provide the access point ARN in place of the bucket
--   name. For more information about access point ARNs, see <a>Using
--   access points</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   When using this action with Amazon S3 on Outposts, you must direct
--   requests to the S3 on Outposts hostname. The S3 on Outposts hostname
--   takes the form
--   <i>AccessPointName</i>-<i>AccountId</i>.<i>outpostID</i>.s3-outposts.<i>Region</i>.amazonaws.com.
--   When using this action using S3 on Outposts through the Amazon Web
--   Services SDKs, you provide the Outposts bucket ARN in place of the
--   bucket name. For more information about S3 on Outposts ARNs, see
--   <a>Using S3 on Outposts</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
putObject_bucket :: Lens' PutObject BucketName

-- | Object key for which the PUT action was initiated.
putObject_key :: Lens' PutObject ObjectKey

-- | Object data.
putObject_body :: Lens' PutObject RequestBody

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newPutObjectResponse</a> smart constructor.
data PutObjectResponse
PutObjectResponse' :: Maybe RequestCharged -> Maybe ETag -> Maybe ObjectVersionId -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe (Sensitive Text) -> Maybe (Sensitive Text) -> Maybe ServerSideEncryption -> Int -> PutObjectResponse
[$sel:requestCharged:PutObjectResponse'] :: PutObjectResponse -> Maybe RequestCharged

-- | Entity tag for the uploaded object.
[$sel:eTag:PutObjectResponse'] :: PutObjectResponse -> Maybe ETag

-- | Version of the object.
[$sel:versionId:PutObjectResponse'] :: PutObjectResponse -> Maybe ObjectVersionId

-- | If the expiration is configured for the object (see
--   <a>PutBucketLifecycleConfiguration</a>), the response includes this
--   header. It includes the expiry-date and rule-id key-value pairs that
--   provide information about object expiration. The value of the rule-id
--   is URL encoded.
[$sel:expiration:PutObjectResponse'] :: PutObjectResponse -> Maybe Text

-- | If server-side encryption with a customer-provided encryption key was
--   requested, the response will include this header confirming the
--   encryption algorithm used.
[$sel:sSECustomerAlgorithm:PutObjectResponse'] :: PutObjectResponse -> Maybe Text

-- | Indicates whether the uploaded object uses an S3 Bucket Key for
--   server-side encryption with Amazon Web Services KMS (SSE-KMS).
[$sel:bucketKeyEnabled:PutObjectResponse'] :: PutObjectResponse -> Maybe Bool

-- | If server-side encryption with a customer-provided encryption key was
--   requested, the response will include this header to provide round-trip
--   message integrity verification of the customer-provided encryption
--   key.
[$sel:sSECustomerKeyMD5:PutObjectResponse'] :: PutObjectResponse -> Maybe Text

-- | If <tt>x-amz-server-side-encryption</tt> is present and has the value
--   of <tt>aws:kms</tt>, this header specifies the ID of the Amazon Web
--   Services Key Management Service (Amazon Web Services KMS) symmetric
--   customer managed key that was used for the object.
[$sel:sSEKMSKeyId:PutObjectResponse'] :: PutObjectResponse -> Maybe (Sensitive Text)

-- | If present, specifies the Amazon Web Services KMS Encryption Context
--   to use for object encryption. The value of this header is a
--   base64-encoded UTF-8 string holding JSON with the encryption context
--   key-value pairs.
[$sel:sSEKMSEncryptionContext:PutObjectResponse'] :: PutObjectResponse -> Maybe (Sensitive Text)

-- | If you specified server-side encryption either with an Amazon Web
--   Services KMS key or Amazon S3-managed encryption key in your PUT
--   request, the response includes this header. It confirms the encryption
--   algorithm that Amazon S3 used to encrypt the object.
[$sel:serverSideEncryption:PutObjectResponse'] :: PutObjectResponse -> Maybe ServerSideEncryption

-- | The response's http status code.
[$sel:httpStatus:PutObjectResponse'] :: PutObjectResponse -> Int

-- | Create a value of <a>PutObjectResponse</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:requestCharged:PutObjectResponse'</a>,
--   <a>putObjectResponse_requestCharged</a> - Undocumented member.
--   
--   <a>$sel:eTag:PutObjectResponse'</a>, <a>putObjectResponse_eTag</a> -
--   Entity tag for the uploaded object.
--   
--   <a>$sel:versionId:PutObjectResponse'</a>,
--   <a>putObjectResponse_versionId</a> - Version of the object.
--   
--   <a>$sel:expiration:PutObjectResponse'</a>,
--   <a>putObjectResponse_expiration</a> - If the expiration is configured
--   for the object (see <a>PutBucketLifecycleConfiguration</a>), the
--   response includes this header. It includes the expiry-date and rule-id
--   key-value pairs that provide information about object expiration. The
--   value of the rule-id is URL encoded.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sSECustomerAlgorithm:PutObject'</a>,
--   <a>putObjectResponse_sSECustomerAlgorithm</a> - If server-side
--   encryption with a customer-provided encryption key was requested, the
--   response will include this header confirming the encryption algorithm
--   used.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bucketKeyEnabled:PutObject'</a>,
--   <a>putObjectResponse_bucketKeyEnabled</a> - Indicates whether the
--   uploaded object uses an S3 Bucket Key for server-side encryption with
--   Amazon Web Services KMS (SSE-KMS).
--   
--   <a>$sel:sSECustomerKeyMD5:PutObject'</a>,
--   <a>putObjectResponse_sSECustomerKeyMD5</a> - If server-side encryption
--   with a customer-provided encryption key was requested, the response
--   will include this header to provide round-trip message integrity
--   verification of the customer-provided encryption key.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sSEKMSKeyId:PutObject'</a>,
--   <a>putObjectResponse_sSEKMSKeyId</a> - If
--   <tt>x-amz-server-side-encryption</tt> is present and has the value of
--   <tt>aws:kms</tt>, this header specifies the ID of the Amazon Web
--   Services Key Management Service (Amazon Web Services KMS) symmetric
--   customer managed key that was used for the object.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sSEKMSEncryptionContext:PutObject'</a>,
--   <a>putObjectResponse_sSEKMSEncryptionContext</a> - If present,
--   specifies the Amazon Web Services KMS Encryption Context to use for
--   object encryption. The value of this header is a base64-encoded UTF-8
--   string holding JSON with the encryption context key-value pairs.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serverSideEncryption:PutObject'</a>,
--   <a>putObjectResponse_serverSideEncryption</a> - If you specified
--   server-side encryption either with an Amazon Web Services KMS key or
--   Amazon S3-managed encryption key in your PUT request, the response
--   includes this header. It confirms the encryption algorithm that Amazon
--   S3 used to encrypt the object.
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:PutObjectResponse'</a>,
--   <a>putObjectResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http status code.
newPutObjectResponse :: Int -> PutObjectResponse

-- | Sets the configuration of the website that is specified in the
--   <tt>website</tt> subresource. To configure a bucket as a website, you
--   can add this subresource on the bucket with website configuration
--   information such as the file name of the index document and any
--   redirect rules. For more information, see <a>Hosting Websites on
--   Amazon S3</a>.
--   
--   This PUT action requires the <tt>S3:PutBucketWebsite</tt> permission.
--   By default, only the bucket owner can configure the website attached
--   to a bucket; however, bucket owners can allow other users to set the
--   website configuration by writing a bucket policy that grants them the
--   <tt>S3:PutBucketWebsite</tt> permission.
--   
--   To redirect all website requests sent to the bucket's website
--   endpoint, you add a website configuration with the following elements.
--   Because all requests are sent to another website, you don't need to
--   provide index document name for the bucket.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><pre>WebsiteConfiguration</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>RedirectAllRequestsTo</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>HostName</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Protocol</pre></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If you want granular control over redirects, you can use the following
--   elements to add routing rules that describe conditions for redirecting
--   requests and information about the redirect destination. In this case,
--   the website configuration must provide an index document for the
--   bucket, because some requests might not be redirected.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><pre>WebsiteConfiguration</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>IndexDocument</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Suffix</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>ErrorDocument</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Key</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>RoutingRules</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>RoutingRule</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Condition</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>HttpErrorCodeReturnedEquals</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>KeyPrefixEquals</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Redirect</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>Protocol</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>HostName</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>ReplaceKeyPrefixWith</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>ReplaceKeyWith</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>HttpRedirectCode</pre></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   Amazon S3 has a limitation of 50 routing rules per website
--   configuration. If you require more than 50 routing rules, you can use
--   object redirect. For more information, see <a>Configuring an Object
--   Redirect</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
module Network.AWS.S3.PutBucketWebsite

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newPutBucketWebsite</a> smart constructor.
data PutBucketWebsite
PutBucketWebsite' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> BucketName -> WebsiteConfiguration -> PutBucketWebsite

-- | The base64-encoded 128-bit MD5 digest of the data. You must use this
--   header as a message integrity check to verify that the request body
--   was not corrupted in transit. For more information, see <a>RFC
--   1864</a>.
--   
--   For requests made using the Amazon Web Services Command Line Interface
--   (CLI) or Amazon Web Services SDKs, this field is calculated
--   automatically.

--   a different account, the request will fail with an HTTP <tt>403
--   (Access Denied)</tt> error.
[$sel:expectedBucketOwner:PutBucketWebsite'] :: PutBucketWebsite -> Maybe Text

-- | The bucket name.
[$sel:bucket:PutBucketWebsite'] :: PutBucketWebsite -> BucketName

-- | Container for the request.
[$sel:websiteConfiguration:PutBucketWebsite'] :: PutBucketWebsite -> WebsiteConfiguration

--   omitted.

--   For more information, see <a>RFC 1864</a>.
--   
--   For requests made using the Amazon Web Services Command Line Interface

--   automatically.

--   <a>putBucketWebsite_expectedBucketOwner</a> - The account ID of the

--   the request will fail with an HTTP <tt>403 (Access Denied)</tt> error.

--   The bucket name.

newPutBucketWebsite :: BucketName -> WebsiteConfiguration -> PutBucketWebsite

-- | Sets the versioning state of an existing bucket. To set the versioning
--   state, you must be the bucket owner.
--   
--   You can set the versioning state with one of the following values:
--   
--   <b>Enabled</b>—Enables versioning for the objects in the bucket. All
--   objects added to the bucket receive a unique version ID.
--   
--   <b>Suspended</b>—Disables versioning for the objects in the bucket.
--   All objects added to the bucket receive the version ID null.
--   
--   If the versioning state has never been set on a bucket, it has no
--   versioning state; a <a>GetBucketVersioning</a> request does not return
--   a versioning state value.
--   
--   If the bucket owner enables MFA Delete in the bucket versioning
--   configuration, the bucket owner must include the <tt>x-amz-mfa
--   request</tt> header and the <tt>Status</tt> and the <tt>MfaDelete</tt>
--   request elements in a request to set the versioning state of the
--   bucket.
--   
--   If you have an object expiration lifecycle policy in your
--   non-versioned bucket and you want to maintain the same permanent
--   delete behavior when you enable versioning, you must add a noncurrent
--   expiration policy. The noncurrent expiration lifecycle policy will
--   manage the deletes of the noncurrent object versions in the
--   version-enabled bucket. (A version-enabled bucket maintains one
--   current and zero or more noncurrent object versions.) For more
--   information, see <a>Lifecycle and Versioning</a>.
--   
--   <b>Related Resources</b>
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><a>CreateBucket</a></li>
--   <li><a>DeleteBucket</a></li>
--   <li><a>GetBucketVersioning</a></li>
--   </ul>
module Network.AWS.S3.PutBucketVersioning

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newPutBucketVersioning</a> smart constructor.
data PutBucketVersioning
PutBucketVersioning' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> BucketName -> VersioningConfiguration -> PutBucketVersioning

-- | The concatenation of the authentication device's serial number, a
--   space, and the value that is displayed on your authentication device.
[$sel:mfa:PutBucketVersioning'] :: PutBucketVersioning -> Maybe Text

-- | <pre>
--   The base64-encoded 128-bit MD5 digest of the data. You must use this
--   </pre>
--   
--   header as a message integrity check to verify that the request body
--   was not corrupted in transit. For more information, see <a>RFC
--   1864</a>.
--   
--   For requests made using the Amazon Web Services Command Line Interface
--   (CLI) or Amazon Web Services SDKs, this field is calculated
--   automatically.
[$sel:contentMD5:PutBucketVersioning'] :: PutBucketVersioning -> Maybe Text

--   a different account, the request will fail with an HTTP <tt>403
--   (Access Denied)</tt> error.

[$sel:bucket:PutBucketVersioning'] :: PutBucketVersioning -> BucketName

--   omitted.

--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:

--   The concatenation of the authentication device's serial number, a
--   space, and the value that is displayed on your authentication device.
--   
--   <a>$sel:contentMD5:PutBucketVersioning'</a>,
--   <a>putBucketVersioning_contentMD5</a> - &gt;The base64-encoded 128-bit
--   MD5 digest of the data. You must use this header as a message
--   integrity check to verify that the request body was not corrupted in
--   transit. For more information, see <a>RFC 1864</a>.
--   
--   For requests made using the Amazon Web Services Command Line Interface

--   automatically.

--   <a>putBucketVersioning_expectedBucketOwner</a> - The account ID of the
--   expected bucket owner. If the bucket is owned by a different account,
--   the request will fail with an HTTP <tt>403 (Access Denied)</tt> error.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bucket:PutBucketVersioning'</a>,
--   <a>putBucketVersioning_bucket</a> - The bucket name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:versioningConfiguration:PutBucketVersioning'</a>,
--   <a>putBucketVersioning_versioningConfiguration</a> - Container for
--   setting the versioning state.

--   The base64-encoded 128-bit MD5 digest of the data. You must use this
--   </pre>

instance Network.AWS.Data.Path.ToPath Network.AWS.S3.PutBucketVersioning.PutBucketVersioning
instance Network.AWS.Data.Query.ToQuery Network.AWS.S3.PutBucketVersioning.PutBucketVersioning


-- | Sets the tags for a bucket.
--   
--   Use tags to organize your Amazon Web Services bill to reflect your own
--   cost structure. To do this, sign up to get your Amazon Web Services
--   account bill with tag key values included. Then, to see the cost of
--   combined resources, organize your billing information according to
--   resources with the same tag key values. For example, you can tag
--   several resources with a specific application name, and then organize
--   your billing information to see the total cost of that application
--   across several services. For more information, see <a>Cost Allocation
--   and Tagging</a> and <a>Using Cost Allocation in Amazon S3 Bucket
--   Tags</a>.
--   
--   When this operation sets the tags for a bucket, it will overwrite any
--   current tags the bucket already has. You cannot use this operation to
--   add tags to an existing list of tags.
--   
--   To use this operation, you must have permissions to perform the
--   <tt>s3:PutBucketTagging</tt> action. The bucket owner has this
--   permission by default and can grant this permission to others. For
--   more information about permissions, see <a>Permissions Related to
--   Bucket Subresource Operations</a> and <a>Managing Access Permissions
--   to Your Amazon S3 Resources</a>.
--   
--   <tt>PutBucketTagging</tt> has the following special errors:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Error code: <tt>InvalidTagError</tt><ul><li>Description: The tag
--   provided was not a valid tag. This error can occur if the tag did not
--   pass input validation. For information about tag restrictions, see
--   <a>User-Defined Tag Restrictions</a> and <a>Amazon Web
--   Services-Generated Cost Allocation Tag
--   Restrictions</a>.</li></ul></li>
--   <li>Error code: <tt>MalformedXMLError</tt><ul><li>Description: The XML
--   provided does not match the schema.</li></ul></li>
--   <li>Error code: <tt>OperationAbortedError </tt><ul><li>Description: A
--   conflicting conditional action is currently in progress against this
--   resource. Please try again.</li></ul></li>
--   <li>Error code: <tt>InternalError</tt><ul><li>Description: The service
--   was unable to apply the provided tag to the bucket.</li></ul></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The following operations are related to <tt>PutBucketTagging</tt>:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><a>GetBucketTagging</a></li>
--   <li><a>DeleteBucketTagging</a></li>
--   </ul>
module Network.AWS.S3.PutBucketTagging

-- | Sets the request payment configuration for a bucket. By default, the
--   bucket owner pays for downloads from the bucket. This configuration
--   parameter enables the bucket owner (only) to specify that the person
--   requesting the download will be charged for the download. For more
--   information, see <a>Requester Pays Buckets</a>.
--   
--   The following operations are related to
--   <tt>PutBucketRequestPayment</tt>:

--   <ul>

--   <li><a>GetBucketRequestPayment</a></li>
--   </ul>

-- | Creates a replication configuration or replaces an existing one. For
--   more information, see <a>Replication</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User
--   Guide</i>.
--   
--   Specify the replication configuration in the request body. In the
--   replication configuration, you provide the name of the destination
--   bucket or buckets where you want Amazon S3 to replicate objects, the
--   IAM role that Amazon S3 can assume to replicate objects on your
--   behalf, and other relevant information.
--   
--   A replication configuration must include at least one rule, and can
--   contain a maximum of 1,000. Each rule identifies a subset of objects
--   to replicate by filtering the objects in the source bucket. To choose
--   additional subsets of objects to replicate, add a rule for each
--   subset.
--   
--   To specify a subset of the objects in the source bucket to apply a
--   replication rule to, add the Filter element as a child of the Rule
--   element. You can filter objects based on an object key prefix, one or
--   more object tags, or both. When you add the Filter element in the
--   configuration, you must also add the following elements:
--   <tt>DeleteMarkerReplication</tt>, <tt>Status</tt>, and
--   <tt>Priority</tt>.
--   
--   If you are using an earlier version of the replication configuration,
--   Amazon S3 handles replication of delete markers differently. For more
--   information, see <a>Backward Compatibility</a>.
--   
--   For information about enabling versioning on a bucket, see <a>Using
--   Versioning</a>.
--   
--   <b>Handling Replication of Encrypted Objects</b>
--   
--   By default, Amazon S3 doesn't replicate objects that are stored at
--   rest using server-side encryption with KMS keys. To replicate Amazon
--   Web Services KMS-encrypted objects, add the following:
--   <tt>SourceSelectionCriteria</tt>, <tt>SseKmsEncryptedObjects</tt>,
--   <tt>Status</tt>, <tt>EncryptionConfiguration</tt>, and
--   <tt>ReplicaKmsKeyID</tt>. For information about replication
--   configuration, see <a>Replicating Objects Created with SSE Using KMS
--   keys</a>.
--   
--   For information on <tt>PutBucketReplication</tt> errors, see <a>List
--   of replication-related error codes</a>
--   
--   <b>Permissions</b>
--   
--   To create a <tt>PutBucketReplication</tt> request, you must have
--   <tt>s3:PutReplicationConfiguration</tt> permissions for the bucket.
--   
--   By default, a resource owner, in this case the Amazon Web Services
--   account that created the bucket, can perform this operation. The
--   resource owner can also grant others permissions to perform the
--   operation. For more information about permissions, see <a>Specifying
--   Permissions in a Policy</a> and <a>Managing Access Permissions to Your
--   Amazon S3 Resources</a>.
--   
--   To perform this operation, the user or role performing the action must
--   have the <a>iam:PassRole</a> permission.
--   
--   The following operations are related to <tt>PutBucketReplication</tt>:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><a>GetBucketReplication</a></li>
--   <li><a>DeleteBucketReplication</a></li>
--   </ul>
module Network.AWS.S3.PutBucketReplication

-- | Applies an Amazon S3 bucket policy to an Amazon S3 bucket. If you are
--   using an identity other than the root user of the Amazon Web Services
--   account that owns the bucket, the calling identity must have the
--   <tt>PutBucketPolicy</tt> permissions on the specified bucket and
--   belong to the bucket owner's account in order to use this operation.
--   
--   If you don't have <tt>PutBucketPolicy</tt> permissions, Amazon S3
--   returns a <tt>403 Access Denied</tt> error. If you have the correct
--   permissions, but you're not using an identity that belongs to the
--   bucket owner's account, Amazon S3 returns a <tt>405 Method Not
--   Allowed</tt> error.
--   
--   As a security precaution, the root user of the Amazon Web Services
--   account that owns a bucket can always use this operation, even if the
--   policy explicitly denies the root user the ability to perform this
--   action.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Bucket policy examples</a>.
--   
--   The following operations are related to <tt>PutBucketPolicy</tt>:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><a>CreateBucket</a></li>
--   <li><a>DeleteBucket</a></li>
--   </ul>
module Network.AWS.S3.PutBucketPolicy

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newPutBucketPolicy</a> smart constructor.
data PutBucketPolicy
PutBucketPolicy' :: Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> BucketName -> ByteString -> PutBucketPolicy

-- | Set this parameter to true to confirm that you want to remove your
--   permissions to change this bucket policy in the future.
[$sel:confirmRemoveSelfBucketAccess:PutBucketPolicy'] :: PutBucketPolicy -> Maybe Bool

-- | The MD5 hash of the request body.
--   
--   For requests made using the Amazon Web Services Command Line Interface
--   (CLI) or Amazon Web Services SDKs, this field is calculated
--   automatically.
[$sel:contentMD5:PutBucketPolicy'] :: PutBucketPolicy -> Maybe Text

-- | The account ID of the expected bucket owner. If the bucket is owned by
--   a different account, the request will fail with an HTTP <tt>403
--   (Access Denied)</tt> error.
[$sel:expectedBucketOwner:PutBucketPolicy'] :: PutBucketPolicy -> Maybe Text

-- | The name of the bucket.
[$sel:bucket:PutBucketPolicy'] :: PutBucketPolicy -> BucketName

-- | The bucket policy as a JSON document.
[$sel:policy:PutBucketPolicy'] :: PutBucketPolicy -> ByteString

-- | Create a value of <a>PutBucketPolicy</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:confirmRemoveSelfBucketAccess:PutBucketPolicy'</a>,
--   <a>putBucketPolicy_confirmRemoveSelfBucketAccess</a> - Set this
--   parameter to true to confirm that you want to remove your permissions
--   to change this bucket policy in the future.
--   
--   <a>$sel:contentMD5:PutBucketPolicy'</a>,
--   <a>putBucketPolicy_contentMD5</a> - The MD5 hash of the request body.
--   
--   For requests made using the Amazon Web Services Command Line Interface
--   (CLI) or Amazon Web Services SDKs, this field is calculated
--   automatically.
--   
--   <a>$sel:expectedBucketOwner:PutBucketPolicy'</a>,
--   <a>putBucketPolicy_expectedBucketOwner</a> - The account ID of the
--   expected bucket owner. If the bucket is owned by a different account,
--   the request will fail with an HTTP <tt>403 (Access Denied)</tt> error.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bucket:PutBucketPolicy'</a>, <a>putBucketPolicy_bucket</a> -
--   The name of the bucket.
--   
--   <a>$sel:policy:PutBucketPolicy'</a>, <a>putBucketPolicy_policy</a> -
--   The bucket policy as a JSON document.
newPutBucketPolicy :: BucketName -> ByteString -> PutBucketPolicy

--   permissions to change this bucket policy in the future.

--   (CLI) or Amazon Web Services SDKs, this field is calculated
--   automatically.

--   (Access Denied)</tt> error.

-- | The name of the bucket.
putBucketPolicy_bucket :: Lens' PutBucketPolicy BucketName

-- | The bucket policy as a JSON document.
putBucketPolicy_policy :: Lens' PutBucketPolicy ByteString

-- | Enables notifications of specified events for a bucket. For more
--   information about event notifications, see <a>Configuring Event
--   Notifications</a>.
--   
--   Using this API, you can replace an existing notification
--   configuration. The configuration is an XML file that defines the event
--   types that you want Amazon S3 to publish and the destination where you
--   want Amazon S3 to publish an event notification when it detects an
--   event of the specified type.
--   
--   By default, your bucket has no event notifications configured. That
--   is, the notification configuration will be an empty
--   <tt>NotificationConfiguration</tt>.
--   
--   <pre>
--   &lt;NotificationConfiguration&gt;
--   </pre>
--   
--   <pre>
--   &lt;/NotificationConfiguration&gt;
--   </pre>
--   
--   This action replaces the existing notification configuration with the
--   configuration you include in the request body.
--   
--   After Amazon S3 receives this request, it first verifies that any
--   Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) or Amazon Simple Queue
--   Service (Amazon SQS) destination exists, and that the bucket owner has
--   permission to publish to it by sending a test notification. In the
--   case of Lambda destinations, Amazon S3 verifies that the Lambda
--   function permissions grant Amazon S3 permission to invoke the function
--   from the Amazon S3 bucket. For more information, see <a>Configuring
--   Notifications for Amazon S3 Events</a>.
--   
--   You can disable notifications by adding the empty
--   NotificationConfiguration element.
--   
--   By default, only the bucket owner can configure notifications on a
--   bucket. However, bucket owners can use a bucket policy to grant
--   permission to other users to set this configuration with
--   <tt>s3:PutBucketNotification</tt> permission.
--   
--   The PUT notification is an atomic operation. For example, suppose your
--   notification configuration includes SNS topic, SQS queue, and Lambda
--   function configurations. When you send a PUT request with this
--   configuration, Amazon S3 sends test messages to your SNS topic. If the
--   message fails, the entire PUT action will fail, and Amazon S3 will not
--   add the configuration to your bucket.
--   
--   <b>Responses</b>
--   
--   If the configuration in the request body includes only one
--   <tt>TopicConfiguration</tt> specifying only the
--   <tt>s3:ReducedRedundancyLostObject</tt> event type, the response will
--   also include the <tt>x-amz-sns-test-message-id</tt> header containing
--   the message ID of the test notification sent to the topic.
--   
--   The following action is related to
--   <tt>PutBucketNotificationConfiguration</tt>:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><a>GetBucketNotificationConfiguration</a></li>
--   </ul>
module Network.AWS.S3.PutBucketNotificationConfiguration

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newPutBucketNotificationConfiguration</a> smart
--   constructor.
data PutBucketNotificationConfiguration
PutBucketNotificationConfiguration' :: Maybe Text -> BucketName -> NotificationConfiguration -> PutBucketNotificationConfiguration

-- | The account ID of the expected bucket owner. If the bucket is owned by
--   a different account, the request will fail with an HTTP <tt>403
--   (Access Denied)</tt> error.
[$sel:expectedBucketOwner:PutBucketNotificationConfiguration'] :: PutBucketNotificationConfiguration -> Maybe Text

-- | The name of the bucket.
[$sel:bucket:PutBucketNotificationConfiguration'] :: PutBucketNotificationConfiguration -> BucketName
[$sel:notificationConfiguration:PutBucketNotificationConfiguration'] :: PutBucketNotificationConfiguration -> NotificationConfiguration

-- | Create a value of <a>PutBucketNotificationConfiguration</a> with all
--   optional fields omitted.

--   fields.

--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:

--   account ID of the expected bucket owner. If the bucket is owned by a
--   different account, the request will fail with an HTTP <tt>403 (Access
--   Denied)</tt> error.

-- | Sets a metrics configuration (specified by the metrics configuration
--   ID) for the bucket. You can have up to 1,000 metrics configurations
--   per bucket. If you're updating an existing metrics configuration, note
--   that this is a full replacement of the existing metrics configuration.
--   If you don't include the elements you want to keep, they are erased.
--   
--   To use this operation, you must have permissions to perform the
--   <tt>s3:PutMetricsConfiguration</tt> action. The bucket owner has this
--   permission by default. The bucket owner can grant this permission to
--   others. For more information about permissions, see <a>Permissions
--   Related to Bucket Subresource Operations</a> and <a>Managing Access
--   Permissions to Your Amazon S3 Resources</a>.
--   
--   For information about CloudWatch request metrics for Amazon S3, see
--   <a>Monitoring Metrics with Amazon CloudWatch</a>.
--   
--   The following operations are related to
--   <tt>PutBucketMetricsConfiguration</tt>:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><a>DeleteBucketMetricsConfiguration</a></li>
--   <li><a>GetBucketMetricsConfiguration</a></li>
--   <li><a>ListBucketMetricsConfigurations</a></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <tt>GetBucketLifecycle</tt> has the following special error:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Error code: <tt>TooManyConfigurations</tt><ul><li>Description: You
--   are attempting to create a new configuration but have already reached
--   the 1,000-configuration limit.</li><li>HTTP Status Code: HTTP 400 Bad
--   Request</li></ul></li>
--   </ul>
module Network.AWS.S3.PutBucketMetricsConfiguration

-- | Set the logging parameters for a bucket and to specify permissions for
--   who can view and modify the logging parameters. All logs are saved to
--   buckets in the same Amazon Web Services Region as the source bucket.
--   To set the logging status of a bucket, you must be the bucket owner.
--   
--   The bucket owner is automatically granted FULL_CONTROL to all logs.
--   You use the <tt>Grantee</tt> request element to grant access to other
--   people. The <tt>Permissions</tt> request element specifies the kind of
--   access the grantee has to the logs.
--   
--   <b>Grantee Values</b>
--   
--   You can specify the person (grantee) to whom you're assigning access
--   rights (using request elements) in the following ways:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>By the person's ID:<pre>&lt;Grantee
--   xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
--   xsi:type="CanonicalUser"&gt;&lt;ID&gt;&lt;&gt;ID&lt;&gt;&lt;/ID&gt;&lt;DisplayName&gt;&lt;&gt;GranteesEmail&lt;&gt;&lt;/DisplayName&gt;
--   &lt;/Grantee&gt;</pre>DisplayName is optional and ignored in the
--   request.</li>
--   <li>By Email address:<pre> &lt;Grantee
--   xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
--   xsi:type="AmazonCustomerByEmail"&gt;&lt;EmailAddress&gt;&lt;&gt;Grantees@email.com&lt;&gt;&lt;/EmailAddress&gt;&lt;/Grantee&gt;</pre>The
--   grantee is resolved to the CanonicalUser and, in a response to a GET
--   Object acl request, appears as the CanonicalUser.</li>
--   <li>By URI:<pre>&lt;Grantee
--   xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
--   xsi:type="Group"&gt;&lt;URI&gt;&lt;&gt;http://acs.amazonaws.com/groups/global/AuthenticatedUsers&lt;&gt;&lt;/URI&gt;&lt;/Grantee&gt;</pre></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   To enable logging, you use LoggingEnabled and its children request
--   elements. To disable logging, you use an empty BucketLoggingStatus
--   request element:
--   
--   <pre>
--   &lt;BucketLoggingStatus xmlns="http://doc.s3.amazonaws.com/2006-03-01" /&gt;
--   </pre>
--   
--   For more information about server access logging, see <a>Server Access
--   Logging</a>.
--   
--   For more information about creating a bucket, see <a>CreateBucket</a>.
--   For more information about returning the logging status of a bucket,
--   see <a>GetBucketLogging</a>.
--   
--   The following operations are related to <tt>PutBucketLogging</tt>:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><a>PutObject</a></li>
--   <li><a>DeleteBucket</a></li>
--   <li><a>CreateBucket</a></li>
--   <li><a>GetBucketLogging</a></li>
--   </ul>
module Network.AWS.S3.PutBucketLogging

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newPutBucketLogging</a> smart constructor.
data PutBucketLogging
PutBucketLogging' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> BucketName -> BucketLoggingStatus -> PutBucketLogging

-- | The MD5 hash of the <tt>PutBucketLogging</tt> request body.
--   
--   For requests made using the Amazon Web Services Command Line Interface
--   (CLI) or Amazon Web Services SDKs, this field is calculated
--   automatically.
[$sel:contentMD5:PutBucketLogging'] :: PutBucketLogging -> Maybe Text

-- | The account ID of the expected bucket owner. If the bucket is owned by
--   a different account, the request will fail with an HTTP <tt>403
--   (Access Denied)</tt> error.
[$sel:expectedBucketOwner:PutBucketLogging'] :: PutBucketLogging -> Maybe Text

-- | The name of the bucket for which to set the logging parameters.
[$sel:bucket:PutBucketLogging'] :: PutBucketLogging -> BucketName

-- | Container for logging status information.
[$sel:bucketLoggingStatus:PutBucketLogging'] :: PutBucketLogging -> BucketLoggingStatus

-- | Create a value of <a>PutBucketLogging</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:contentMD5:PutBucketLogging'</a>,
--   <a>putBucketLogging_contentMD5</a> - The MD5 hash of the
--   <tt>PutBucketLogging</tt> request body.
--   
--   For requests made using the Amazon Web Services Command Line Interface
--   (CLI) or Amazon Web Services SDKs, this field is calculated
--   automatically.
--   
--   <a>$sel:expectedBucketOwner:PutBucketLogging'</a>,
--   <a>putBucketLogging_expectedBucketOwner</a> - The account ID of the
--   expected bucket owner. If the bucket is owned by a different account,
--   the request will fail with an HTTP <tt>403 (Access Denied)</tt> error.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bucket:PutBucketLogging'</a>, <a>putBucketLogging_bucket</a> -
--   The name of the bucket for which to set the logging parameters.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bucketLoggingStatus:PutBucketLogging'</a>,
--   <a>putBucketLogging_bucketLoggingStatus</a> - Container for logging
--   status information.

-- | Creates a new lifecycle configuration for the bucket or replaces an
--   existing lifecycle configuration. For information about lifecycle
--   configuration, see <a>Managing your storage lifecycle</a>.
--   
--   Bucket lifecycle configuration now supports specifying a lifecycle
--   rule using an object key name prefix, one or more object tags, or a
--   combination of both. Accordingly, this section describes the latest
--   API. The previous version of the API supported filtering based only on
--   an object key name prefix, which is supported for backward
--   compatibility. For the related API description, see
--   <a>PutBucketLifecycle</a>.
--   
--   <b>Rules</b>
--   
--   You specify the lifecycle configuration in your request body. The
--   lifecycle configuration is specified as XML consisting of one or more
--   rules. Each rule consists of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Filter identifying a subset of objects to which the rule applies.
--   The filter can be based on a key name prefix, object tags, or a
--   combination of both.</li>
--   <li>Status whether the rule is in effect.</li>
--   <li>One or more lifecycle transition and expiration actions that you
--   want Amazon S3 to perform on the objects identified by the filter. If
--   the state of your bucket is versioning-enabled or
--   versioning-suspended, you can have many versions of the same object
--   (one current version and zero or more noncurrent versions). Amazon S3
--   provides predefined actions that you can specify for current and
--   noncurrent object versions.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Object Lifecycle Management</a> and
--   <a>Lifecycle Configuration Elements</a>.
--   
--   <b>Permissions</b>
--   
--   By default, all Amazon S3 resources are private, including buckets,
--   objects, and related subresources (for example, lifecycle
--   configuration and website configuration). Only the resource owner
--   (that is, the Amazon Web Services account that created it) can access
--   the resource. The resource owner can optionally grant access
--   permissions to others by writing an access policy. For this operation,
--   a user must get the s3:PutLifecycleConfiguration permission.
--   
--   You can also explicitly deny permissions. Explicit deny also
--   supersedes any other permissions. If you want to block users or
--   accounts from removing or deleting objects from your bucket, you must
--   deny them permissions for the following actions:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>s3:DeleteObject</li>
--   <li>s3:DeleteObjectVersion</li>
--   <li>s3:PutLifecycleConfiguration</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about permissions, see <a>Managing Access
--   Permissions to Your Amazon S3 Resources</a>.
--   
--   The following are related to <tt>PutBucketLifecycleConfiguration</tt>:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><a>Examples of Lifecycle Configuration</a></li>
--   <li><a>GetBucketLifecycleConfiguration</a></li>
--   <li><a>DeleteBucketLifecycle</a></li>
--   </ul>
module Network.AWS.S3.PutBucketLifecycleConfiguration

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newPutBucketLifecycleConfiguration</a> smart
--   constructor.
data PutBucketLifecycleConfiguration
PutBucketLifecycleConfiguration' :: Maybe BucketLifecycleConfiguration -> Maybe Text -> BucketName -> PutBucketLifecycleConfiguration

-- | Container for lifecycle rules. You can add as many as 1,000 rules.
[$sel:lifecycleConfiguration:PutBucketLifecycleConfiguration'] :: PutBucketLifecycleConfiguration -> Maybe BucketLifecycleConfiguration

-- | The account ID of the expected bucket owner. If the bucket is owned by
--   a different account, the request will fail with an HTTP <tt>403
--   (Access Denied)</tt> error.
[$sel:expectedBucketOwner:PutBucketLifecycleConfiguration'] :: PutBucketLifecycleConfiguration -> Maybe Text

--   optional fields omitted.

--   account ID of the expected bucket owner. If the bucket is owned by a

--

-- | This implementation of the <tt>PUT</tt> action adds an inventory
--   configuration (identified by the inventory ID) to the bucket. You can
--   have up to 1,000 inventory configurations per bucket.
--   
--   Amazon S3 inventory generates inventories of the objects in the bucket
--   on a daily or weekly basis, and the results are published to a flat
--   file. The bucket that is inventoried is called the <i>source</i>
--   bucket, and the bucket where the inventory flat file is stored is
--   called the <i>destination</i> bucket. The <i>destination</i> bucket
--   must be in the same Amazon Web Services Region as the <i>source</i>
--   bucket.
--   
--   When you configure an inventory for a <i>source</i> bucket, you
--   specify the <i>destination</i> bucket where you want the inventory to
--   be stored, and whether to generate the inventory daily or weekly. You
--   can also configure what object metadata to include and whether to
--   inventory all object versions or only current versions. For more
--   information, see <a>Amazon S3 Inventory</a> in the Amazon S3 User
--   Guide.
--   
--   You must create a bucket policy on the <i>destination</i> bucket to
--   grant permissions to Amazon S3 to write objects to the bucket in the
--   defined location. For an example policy, see <a>Granting Permissions
--   for Amazon S3 Inventory and Storage Class Analysis</a>.
--   
--   To use this operation, you must have permissions to perform the
--   <tt>s3:PutInventoryConfiguration</tt> action. The bucket owner has
--   this permission by default and can grant this permission to others.
--   For more information about permissions, see <a>Permissions Related to
--   Bucket Subresource Operations</a> and <a>Managing Access Permissions
--   to Your Amazon S3 Resources</a> in the Amazon S3 User Guide.
--   
--   <b>Special Errors</b>
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b>HTTP 400 Bad Request Error</b><ul><li><i>Code:</i>
--   InvalidArgument</li><li><i>Cause:</i> Invalid Argument</li></ul></li>
--   <li><b>HTTP 400 Bad Request Error</b><ul><li><i>Code:</i>
--   TooManyConfigurations</li><li><i>Cause:</i> You are attempting to
--   create a new configuration but have already reached the
--   1,000-configuration limit.</li></ul></li>
--   <li><b>HTTP 403 Forbidden Error</b><ul><li><i>Code:</i>
--   AccessDenied</li><li><i>Cause:</i> You are not the owner of the
--   specified bucket, or you do not have the
--   <tt>s3:PutInventoryConfiguration</tt> bucket permission to set the
--   configuration on the bucket.</li></ul></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <b>Related Resources</b>
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><a>GetBucketInventoryConfiguration</a></li>
--   <li><a>DeleteBucketInventoryConfiguration</a></li>
--   <li><a>ListBucketInventoryConfigurations</a></li>
--   </ul>
module Network.AWS.S3.PutBucketInventoryConfiguration

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newPutBucketInventoryConfiguration</a> smart
--   constructor.

-- | Puts a S3 Intelligent-Tiering configuration to the specified bucket.
--   You can have up to 1,000 S3 Intelligent-Tiering configurations per
--   bucket.
--   
--   The S3 Intelligent-Tiering storage class is designed to optimize
--   storage costs by automatically moving data to the most cost-effective
--   storage access tier, without performance impact or operational
--   overhead. S3 Intelligent-Tiering delivers automatic cost savings in
--   two low latency and high throughput access tiers. For data that can be
--   accessed asynchronously, you can choose to activate automatic
--   archiving capabilities within the S3 Intelligent-Tiering storage
--   class.
--   
--   The S3 Intelligent-Tiering storage class is the ideal storage class
--   for data with unknown, changing, or unpredictable access patterns,
--   independent of object size or retention period. If the size of an
--   object is less than 128 KB, it is not eligible for auto-tiering.
--   Smaller objects can be stored, but they are always charged at the
--   Frequent Access tier rates in the S3 Intelligent-Tiering storage
--   class.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Storage class for automatically
--   optimizing frequently and infrequently accessed objects</a>.
--   
--   Operations related to
--   <tt>PutBucketIntelligentTieringConfiguration</tt> include:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><a>DeleteBucketIntelligentTieringConfiguration</a></li>
--   <li><a>GetBucketIntelligentTieringConfiguration</a></li>
--   <li><a>ListBucketIntelligentTieringConfigurations</a></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   You only need S3 Intelligent-Tiering enabled on a bucket if you want
--   to automatically move objects stored in the S3 Intelligent-Tiering
--   storage class to the Archive Access or Deep Archive Access tier.
--   
--   <b>Special Errors</b>
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b>HTTP 400 Bad Request Error</b><ul><li><i>Code:</i>
--   InvalidArgument</li><li><i>Cause:</i> Invalid Argument</li></ul></li>
--   <li><b>HTTP 400 Bad Request Error</b><ul><li><i>Code:</i>
--   TooManyConfigurations</li><li><i>Cause:</i> You are attempting to
--   create a new configuration but have already reached the
--   1,000-configuration limit.</li></ul></li>
--   <li><b>HTTP 403 Forbidden Error</b><ul><li><i>Code:</i>
--   AccessDenied</li><li><i>Cause:</i> You are not the owner of the
--   specified bucket, or you do not have the
--   <tt>s3:PutIntelligentTieringConfiguration</tt> bucket permission to
--   set the configuration on the bucket.</li></ul></li>
--   </ul>
module Network.AWS.S3.PutBucketIntelligentTieringConfiguration

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newPutBucketIntelligentTieringConfiguration</a> smart
--   constructor.
data PutBucketIntelligentTieringConfiguration

-- | This action uses the <tt>encryption</tt> subresource to configure
--   default encryption and Amazon S3 Bucket Key for an existing bucket.
--   
--   Default encryption for a bucket can use server-side encryption with
--   Amazon S3-managed keys (SSE-S3) or customer managed keys (SSE-KMS). If
--   you specify default encryption using SSE-KMS, you can also configure
--   Amazon S3 Bucket Key. For information about default encryption, see
--   <a>Amazon S3 default bucket encryption</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User
--   Guide</i>. For more information about S3 Bucket Keys, see <a>Amazon S3
--   Bucket Keys</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   This action requires Amazon Web Services Signature Version 4. For more
--   information, see <a>Authenticating Requests (Amazon Web Services
--   Signature Version 4)</a>.
--   
--   To use this operation, you must have permissions to perform the
--   <tt>s3:PutEncryptionConfiguration</tt> action. The bucket owner has
--   this permission by default. The bucket owner can grant this permission
--   to others. For more information about permissions, see <a>Permissions
--   Related to Bucket Subresource Operations</a> and <a>Managing Access
--   Permissions to Your Amazon S3 Resources</a> in the Amazon S3 User
--   Guide.
--   
--   <b>Related Resources</b>
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><a>GetBucketEncryption</a></li>
--   <li><a>DeleteBucketEncryption</a></li>
--   </ul>
module Network.AWS.S3.PutBucketEncryption
