-- | This action initiates a multipart upload and returns an upload ID.
--   This upload ID is used to associate all of the parts in the specific
--   multipart upload. You specify this upload ID in each of your
--   subsequent upload part requests (see <a>UploadPart</a>). You also
--   include this upload ID in the final request to either complete or
--   abort the multipart upload request.
--   
--   For more information about multipart uploads, see <a>Multipart Upload
--   Overview</a>.
--   
--   If you have configured a lifecycle rule to abort incomplete multipart
--   uploads, the upload must complete within the number of days specified
--   in the bucket lifecycle configuration. Otherwise, the incomplete
--   multipart upload becomes eligible for an abort action and Amazon S3
--   aborts the multipart upload. For more information, see <a>Aborting
--   Incomplete Multipart Uploads Using a Bucket Lifecycle Policy</a>.
--   
--   For information about the permissions required to use the multipart
--   upload API, see <a>Multipart Upload and Permissions</a>.
--   
--   For request signing, multipart upload is just a series of regular
--   requests. You initiate a multipart upload, send one or more requests
--   to upload parts, and then complete the multipart upload process. You
--   sign each request individually. There is nothing special about signing
--   multipart upload requests. For more information about signing, see
--   <a>Authenticating Requests (Amazon Web Services Signature Version
--   4)</a>.
--   
--   After you initiate a multipart upload and upload one or more parts, to
--   stop being charged for storing the uploaded parts, you must either
--   complete or abort the multipart upload. Amazon S3 frees up the space
--   used to store the parts and stop charging you for storing them only
--   after you either complete or abort a multipart upload.
--   
--   You can optionally request server-side encryption. For server-side
--   encryption, Amazon S3 encrypts your data as it writes it to disks in
--   its data centers and decrypts it when you access it. You can provide
--   your own encryption key, or use Amazon Web Services KMS keys or Amazon
--   S3-managed encryption keys. If you choose to provide your own
--   encryption key, the request headers you provide in <a>UploadPart</a>
--   and <a>UploadPartCopy</a> requests must match the headers you used in
--   the request to initiate the upload by using
--   <tt>CreateMultipartUpload</tt>.
--   
--   To perform a multipart upload with encryption using an Amazon Web
--   Services KMS key, the requester must have permission to the
--   <tt>kms:Decrypt</tt> and <tt>kms:GenerateDataKey*</tt> actions on the
--   key. These permissions are required because Amazon S3 must decrypt and
--   read data from the encrypted file parts before it completes the
--   multipart upload. For more information, see <a>Multipart upload API
--   and permissions</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   If your Identity and Access Management (IAM) user or role is in the
--   same Amazon Web Services account as the KMS key, then you must have
--   these permissions on the key policy. If your IAM user or role belongs
--   to a different account than the key, then you must have the
--   permissions on both the key policy and your IAM user or role.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Protecting Data Using Server-Side
--   Encryption</a>.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><i>Access Permissions</i> When copying an object, you can
--   optionally specify the accounts or groups that should be granted
--   specific permissions on the new object. There are two ways to grant
--   the permissions using the request headers:<ul><li>Specify a canned ACL
--   with the <tt>x-amz-acl</tt> request header. For more information, see
--   <a>Canned ACL</a>.</li><li>Specify access permissions explicitly with
--   the <tt>x-amz-grant-read</tt>, <tt>x-amz-grant-read-acp</tt>,
--   <tt>x-amz-grant-write-acp</tt>, and <tt>x-amz-grant-full-control</tt>
--   headers. These parameters map to the set of permissions that Amazon S3
--   supports in an ACL. For more information, see <a>Access Control List
--   (ACL) Overview</a>.</li></ul>You can use either a canned ACL or
--   specify access permissions explicitly. You cannot do both.</li>
--   <li><i>Server-Side- Encryption-Specific Request Headers</i> You can
--   optionally tell Amazon S3 to encrypt data at rest using server-side
--   encryption. Server-side encryption is for data encryption at rest.
--   Amazon S3 encrypts your data as it writes it to disks in its data
--   centers and decrypts it when you access it. The option you use depends
--   on whether you want to use Amazon Web Services managed encryption keys
--   or provide your own encryption key.<ul><li>Use encryption keys managed
--   by Amazon S3 or customer managed key stored in Amazon Web Services Key
--   Management Service (Amazon Web Services KMS) – If you want Amazon Web
--   Services to manage the keys used to encrypt data, specify the
--   following headers in the
--   request.<ul><li>x-amz-server-side-encryption</li><li>x-amz-server-side-encryption-aws-kms-key-id</li><li>x-amz-server-side-encryption-context</li></ul>If
--   you specify <tt>x-amz-server-side-encryption:aws:kms</tt>, but don't
--   provide <tt>x-amz-server-side-encryption-aws-kms-key-id</tt>, Amazon
--   S3 uses the Amazon Web Services managed key in Amazon Web Services KMS
--   to protect the data.All GET and PUT requests for an object protected
--   by Amazon Web Services KMS fail if you don't make them with SSL or by
--   using SigV4.For more information about server-side encryption with KMS
--   key (SSE-KMS), see <a>Protecting Data Using Server-Side Encryption
--   with KMS keys</a>.</li><li>Use customer-provided encryption keys – If
--   you want to manage your own encryption keys, provide all the following
--   headers in the
--   request.<ul><li>x-amz-server-side-encryption-customer-algorithm</li><li>x-amz-server-side-encryption-customer-key</li><li>x-amz-server-side-encryption-customer-key-MD5</li></ul>For
--   more information about server-side encryption with KMS keys (SSE-KMS),
--   see <a>Protecting Data Using Server-Side Encryption with KMS
--   keys</a>.</li></ul></li>
--   <li><i>Access-Control-List (ACL)-Specific Request Headers</i> You also
--   can use the following access control–related headers with this
--   operation. By default, all objects are private. Only the owner has
--   full access control. When adding a new object, you can grant
--   permissions to individual Amazon Web Services accounts or to
--   predefined groups defined by Amazon S3. These permissions are then
--   added to the access control list (ACL) on the object. For more
--   information, see <a>Using ACLs</a>. With this operation, you can grant
--   access permissions using one of the following two
--   methods:<ul><li>Specify a canned ACL (<tt>x-amz-acl</tt>) — Amazon S3
--   supports a set of predefined ACLs, known as <i>canned ACLs</i>. Each
--   canned ACL has a predefined set of grantees and permissions. For more
--   information, see <a>Canned ACL</a>.</li><li>Specify access permissions
--   explicitly — To explicitly grant access permissions to specific Amazon
--   Web Services accounts or groups, use the following headers. Each
--   header maps to specific permissions that Amazon S3 supports in an ACL.
--   For more information, see <a>Access Control List (ACL) Overview</a>.
--   In the header, you specify a list of grantees who get the specific
--   permission. To grant permissions explicitly,
--   use:<ul><li>x-amz-grant-read</li><li>x-amz-grant-write</li><li>x-amz-grant-read-acp</li><li>x-amz-grant-write-acp</li><li>x-amz-grant-full-control</li></ul>You
--   specify each grantee as a type=value pair, where the type is one of
--   the following:<ul><li><tt>id</tt> – if the value specified is the
--   canonical user ID of an Amazon Web Services
--   account</li><li><tt>uri</tt> – if you are granting permissions to a
--   predefined group</li><li><tt>emailAddress</tt> – if the value
--   specified is the email address of an Amazon Web Services accountUsing
--   email addresses to specify a grantee is only supported in the
--   following Amazon Web Services Regions:<ul><li>US East (N.
--   Virginia)</li><li>US West (N. California)</li><li>US West
--   (Oregon)</li><li>Asia Pacific (Singapore)</li><li>Asia Pacific
--   (Sydney)</li><li>Asia Pacific (Tokyo)</li><li>Europe
--   (Ireland)</li><li>South America (São Paulo)</li></ul>For a list of all
--   the Amazon S3 supported Regions and endpoints, see <a>Regions and
--   Endpoints</a> in the Amazon Web Services General
--   Reference.</li></ul>For example, the following
--   <tt>x-amz-grant-read</tt> header grants the Amazon Web Services
--   accounts identified by account IDs permissions to read object data and
--   its metadata:<pre>x-amz-grant-read: id="11112222333",
--   id="444455556666"</pre></li></ul></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The following operations are related to
--   <tt>CreateMultipartUpload</tt>:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><a>UploadPart</a></li>
--   <li><a>CompleteMultipartUpload</a></li>
--   <li><a>AbortMultipartUpload</a></li>
--   <li><a>ListParts</a></li>
--   <li><a>ListMultipartUploads</a></li>
--   </ul>
module Network.AWS.S3.CreateMultipartUpload

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateMultipartUpload</a> smart constructor.
data CreateMultipartUpload
CreateMultipartUpload' :: Maybe ObjectLockMode -> Maybe ISO8601 -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe (Sensitive Text) -> Maybe RequestPayer -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe StorageClass -> Maybe Text -> Maybe (Sensitive Text) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe ISO8601 -> HashMap Text Text -> Maybe (Sensitive Text) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe ObjectLockLegalHoldStatus -> Maybe ObjectCannedACL -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe ServerSideEncryption -> Maybe Text -> BucketName -> ObjectKey -> CreateMultipartUpload

-- | Specifies the Object Lock mode that you want to apply to the uploaded
--   object.
[$sel:objectLockMode:CreateMultipartUpload'] :: CreateMultipartUpload -> Maybe ObjectLockMode

-- | The date and time at which the object is no longer cacheable.
[$sel:expires:CreateMultipartUpload'] :: CreateMultipartUpload -> Maybe ISO8601

-- | Allows grantee to read the object ACL.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
[$sel:grantReadACP:CreateMultipartUpload'] :: CreateMultipartUpload -> Maybe Text

-- | Specifies the algorithm to use to when encrypting the object (for
--   example, AES256).
[$sel:sSECustomerAlgorithm:CreateMultipartUpload'] :: CreateMultipartUpload -> Maybe Text

-- | Specifies the customer-provided encryption key for Amazon S3 to use in
--   encrypting data. This value is used to store the object and then it is
--   discarded; Amazon S3 does not store the encryption key. The key must
--   be appropriate for use with the algorithm specified in the
--   <tt>x-amz-server-side-encryption-customer-algorithm</tt> header.
[$sel:sSECustomerKey:CreateMultipartUpload'] :: CreateMultipartUpload -> Maybe (Sensitive Text)
[$sel:requestPayer:CreateMultipartUpload'] :: CreateMultipartUpload -> Maybe RequestPayer

-- | Allows grantee to write the ACL for the applicable object.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
[$sel:grantWriteACP:CreateMultipartUpload'] :: CreateMultipartUpload -> Maybe Text

-- | Specifies whether Amazon S3 should use an S3 Bucket Key for object
--   encryption with server-side encryption using AWS KMS (SSE-KMS).
--   Setting this header to <tt>true</tt> causes Amazon S3 to use an S3
--   Bucket Key for object encryption with SSE-KMS.
--   
--   Specifying this header with an object action doesn’t affect
--   bucket-level settings for S3 Bucket Key.
[$sel:bucketKeyEnabled:CreateMultipartUpload'] :: CreateMultipartUpload -> Maybe Bool

-- | If the bucket is configured as a website, redirects requests for this
--   object to another object in the same bucket or to an external URL.
--   Amazon S3 stores the value of this header in the object metadata.
[$sel:websiteRedirectLocation:CreateMultipartUpload'] :: CreateMultipartUpload -> Maybe Text

-- | Allows grantee to read the object data and its metadata.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
[$sel:grantRead:CreateMultipartUpload'] :: CreateMultipartUpload -> Maybe Text

-- | By default, Amazon S3 uses the STANDARD Storage Class to store newly
--   created objects. The STANDARD storage class provides high durability
--   and high availability. Depending on performance needs, you can specify
--   a different Storage Class. Amazon S3 on Outposts only uses the
--   OUTPOSTS Storage Class. For more information, see <a>Storage
--   Classes</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
[$sel:storageClass:CreateMultipartUpload'] :: CreateMultipartUpload -> Maybe StorageClass

-- | Specifies the 128-bit MD5 digest of the encryption key according to
--   RFC 1321. Amazon S3 uses this header for a message integrity check to
--   ensure that the encryption key was transmitted without error.
[$sel:sSECustomerKeyMD5:CreateMultipartUpload'] :: CreateMultipartUpload -> Maybe Text

-- | Specifies the ID of the symmetric customer managed key to use for
--   object encryption. All GET and PUT requests for an object protected by
--   Amazon Web Services KMS will fail if not made via SSL or using SigV4.
--   For information about configuring using any of the officially
--   supported Amazon Web Services SDKs and Amazon Web Services CLI, see
--   <a>Specifying the Signature Version in Request Authentication</a> in
--   the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
[$sel:sSEKMSKeyId:CreateMultipartUpload'] :: CreateMultipartUpload -> Maybe (Sensitive Text)

-- | Gives the grantee READ, READ_ACP, and WRITE_ACP permissions on the
--   object.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
[$sel:grantFullControl:CreateMultipartUpload'] :: CreateMultipartUpload -> Maybe Text

-- | Specifies what content encodings have been applied to the object and
--   thus what decoding mechanisms must be applied to obtain the media-type
--   referenced by the Content-Type header field.
[$sel:contentEncoding:CreateMultipartUpload'] :: CreateMultipartUpload -> Maybe Text

[$sel:tagging:CreateMultipartUpload'] :: CreateMultipartUpload -> Maybe Text

[$sel:objectLockRetainUntilDate:CreateMultipartUpload'] :: CreateMultipartUpload -> Maybe ISO8601

[$sel:metadata:CreateMultipartUpload'] :: CreateMultipartUpload -> HashMap Text Text

-- | Specifies the Amazon Web Services KMS Encryption Context to use for
--   object encryption. The value of this header is a base64-encoded UTF-8
--   string holding JSON with the encryption context key-value pairs.
[$sel:sSEKMSEncryptionContext:CreateMultipartUpload'] :: CreateMultipartUpload -> Maybe (Sensitive Text)

[$sel:cacheControl:CreateMultipartUpload'] :: CreateMultipartUpload -> Maybe Text

[$sel:contentLanguage:CreateMultipartUpload'] :: CreateMultipartUpload -> Maybe Text

--   object.

[$sel:acl:CreateMultipartUpload'] :: CreateMultipartUpload -> Maybe ObjectCannedACL

[$sel:contentDisposition:CreateMultipartUpload'] :: CreateMultipartUpload -> Maybe Text

--   (Access Denied)</tt> error.
[$sel:expectedBucketOwner:CreateMultipartUpload'] :: CreateMultipartUpload -> Maybe Text

--   Amazon S3 (for example, AES256, aws:kms).
[$sel:serverSideEncryption:CreateMultipartUpload'] :: CreateMultipartUpload -> Maybe ServerSideEncryption

[$sel:contentType:CreateMultipartUpload'] :: CreateMultipartUpload -> Maybe Text

-- | The name of the bucket to which to initiate the upload
--   
--   When using this action with an access point, you must direct requests
--   to the access point hostname. The access point hostname takes the form
--   <i>AccessPointName</i>-<i>AccountId</i>.s3-accesspoint.<i>Region</i>.amazonaws.com.
--   When using this action with an access point through the Amazon Web
--   Services SDKs, you provide the access point ARN in place of the bucket
--   name. For more information about access point ARNs, see <a>Using
--   access points</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   When using this action with Amazon S3 on Outposts, you must direct
--   requests to the S3 on Outposts hostname. The S3 on Outposts hostname
--   takes the form
--   <i>AccessPointName</i>-<i>AccountId</i>.<i>outpostID</i>.s3-outposts.<i>Region</i>.amazonaws.com.
--   When using this action using S3 on Outposts through the Amazon Web
--   Services SDKs, you provide the Outposts bucket ARN in place of the
--   bucket name. For more information about S3 on Outposts ARNs, see
--   <a>Using S3 on Outposts</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
[$sel:bucket:CreateMultipartUpload'] :: CreateMultipartUpload -> BucketName

-- | Object key for which the multipart upload is to be initiated.
[$sel:key:CreateMultipartUpload'] :: CreateMultipartUpload -> ObjectKey

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateMultipartUpload</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:objectLockMode:CreateMultipartUpload'</a>,
--   <a>createMultipartUpload_objectLockMode</a> - Specifies the Object
--   Lock mode that you want to apply to the uploaded object.
--   
--   <a>$sel:expires:CreateMultipartUpload'</a>,
--   <a>createMultipartUpload_expires</a> - The date and time at which the
--   object is no longer cacheable.
--   
--   <a>$sel:grantReadACP:CreateMultipartUpload'</a>,
--   <a>createMultipartUpload_grantReadACP</a> - Allows grantee to read the
--   object ACL.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sSECustomerAlgorithm:CreateMultipartUpload'</a>,
--   <a>createMultipartUpload_sSECustomerAlgorithm</a> - Specifies the
--   algorithm to use to when encrypting the object (for example, AES256).
--   
--   <a>$sel:sSECustomerKey:CreateMultipartUpload'</a>,
--   <a>createMultipartUpload_sSECustomerKey</a> - Specifies the
--   customer-provided encryption key for Amazon S3 to use in encrypting
--   data. This value is used to store the object and then it is discarded;
--   Amazon S3 does not store the encryption key. The key must be
--   appropriate for use with the algorithm specified in the
--   <tt>x-amz-server-side-encryption-customer-algorithm</tt> header.
--   
--   <a>$sel:requestPayer:CreateMultipartUpload'</a>,
--   <a>createMultipartUpload_requestPayer</a> - Undocumented member.
--   
--   <a>$sel:grantWriteACP:CreateMultipartUpload'</a>,
--   <a>createMultipartUpload_grantWriteACP</a> - Allows grantee to write
--   the ACL for the applicable object.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bucketKeyEnabled:CreateMultipartUpload'</a>,
--   <a>createMultipartUpload_bucketKeyEnabled</a> - Specifies whether
--   Amazon S3 should use an S3 Bucket Key for object encryption with
--   server-side encryption using AWS KMS (SSE-KMS). Setting this header to
--   <tt>true</tt> causes Amazon S3 to use an S3 Bucket Key for object
--   encryption with SSE-KMS.
--   
--   Specifying this header with an object action doesn’t affect
--   bucket-level settings for S3 Bucket Key.
--   
--   <a>$sel:websiteRedirectLocation:CreateMultipartUpload'</a>,
--   <a>createMultipartUpload_websiteRedirectLocation</a> - If the bucket
--   is configured as a website, redirects requests for this object to
--   another object in the same bucket or to an external URL. Amazon S3
--   stores the value of this header in the object metadata.
--   
--   <a>$sel:grantRead:CreateMultipartUpload'</a>,
--   <a>createMultipartUpload_grantRead</a> - Allows grantee to read the
--   object data and its metadata.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
--   
--   <a>$sel:storageClass:CreateMultipartUpload'</a>,
--   <a>createMultipartUpload_storageClass</a> - By default, Amazon S3 uses
--   the STANDARD Storage Class to store newly created objects. The
--   STANDARD storage class provides high durability and high availability.
--   Depending on performance needs, you can specify a different Storage
--   Class. Amazon S3 on Outposts only uses the OUTPOSTS Storage Class. For
--   more information, see <a>Storage Classes</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User
--   Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sSECustomerKeyMD5:CreateMultipartUpload'</a>,
--   <a>createMultipartUpload_sSECustomerKeyMD5</a> - Specifies the 128-bit
--   MD5 digest of the encryption key according to RFC 1321. Amazon S3 uses
--   this header for a message integrity check to ensure that the
--   encryption key was transmitted without error.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sSEKMSKeyId:CreateMultipartUpload'</a>,
--   <a>createMultipartUpload_sSEKMSKeyId</a> - Specifies the ID of the
--   symmetric customer managed key to use for object encryption. All GET
--   and PUT requests for an object protected by Amazon Web Services KMS
--   will fail if not made via SSL or using SigV4. For information about
--   configuring using any of the officially supported Amazon Web Services
--   SDKs and Amazon Web Services CLI, see <a>Specifying the Signature
--   Version in Request Authentication</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User
--   Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:grantFullControl:CreateMultipartUpload'</a>,
--   <a>createMultipartUpload_grantFullControl</a> - Gives the grantee
--   READ, READ_ACP, and WRITE_ACP permissions on the object.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
--   
--   <a>$sel:contentEncoding:CreateMultipartUpload'</a>,
--   <a>createMultipartUpload_contentEncoding</a> - Specifies what content
--   encodings have been applied to the object and thus what decoding
--   mechanisms must be applied to obtain the media-type referenced by the
--   Content-Type header field.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tagging:CreateMultipartUpload'</a>,
--   <a>createMultipartUpload_tagging</a> - The tag-set for the object. The
--   tag-set must be encoded as URL Query parameters.
--   
--   <a>$sel:objectLockRetainUntilDate:CreateMultipartUpload'</a>,
--   <a>createMultipartUpload_objectLockRetainUntilDate</a> - Specifies the
--   date and time when you want the Object Lock to expire.
--   
--   <a>$sel:metadata:CreateMultipartUpload'</a>,

--   with the object in S3.
--

--   Amazon Web Services KMS Encryption Context to use for object
--   encryption. The value of this header is a base64-encoded UTF-8 string

--   to initiate the upload
--   
--   When using this action with an access point, you must direct requests
--   to the access point hostname. The access point hostname takes the form
--   <i>AccessPointName</i>-<i>AccountId</i>.s3-accesspoint.<i>Region</i>.amazonaws.com.
--   When using this action with an access point through the Amazon Web
--   Services SDKs, you provide the access point ARN in place of the bucket

--   access points</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.

--   takes the form
--   <i>AccessPointName</i>-<i>AccountId</i>.<i>outpostID</i>.s3-outposts.<i>Region</i>.amazonaws.com.

--   upload is to be initiated.

-- | If the bucket has a lifecycle rule configured with an action to abort
--   incomplete multipart uploads and the prefix in the lifecycle rule
--   matches the object name in the request, the response includes this
--   header. The header indicates when the initiated multipart upload
--   becomes eligible for an abort operation. For more information, see
--   <a>Aborting Incomplete Multipart Uploads Using a Bucket Lifecycle
--   Policy</a>.
--   
--   The response also includes the <tt>x-amz-abort-rule-id</tt> header
--   that provides the ID of the lifecycle configuration rule that defines
--   this action.

--   that provides the ID of the lifecycle configuration rule that defines
--   this action.
createMultipartUploadResponse_abortDate :: Lens' CreateMultipartUploadResponse (Maybe UTCTime)

-- | This header is returned along with the <tt>x-amz-abort-date</tt>
--   header. It identifies the applicable lifecycle configuration rule that
--   defines the action to abort incomplete multipart uploads.
createMultipartUploadResponse_abortRuleId :: Lens' CreateMultipartUploadResponse (Maybe Text)

-- | Indicates whether the multipart upload uses an S3 Bucket Key for
--   server-side encryption with Amazon Web Services KMS (SSE-KMS).
createMultipartUploadResponse_bucketKeyEnabled :: Lens' CreateMultipartUploadResponse (Maybe Bool)

-- | Object key for which the multipart upload was initiated.
createMultipartUploadResponse_key :: Lens' CreateMultipartUploadResponse (Maybe ObjectKey)

-- | If server-side encryption with a customer-provided encryption key was
--   requested, the response will include this header to provide round-trip
--   message integrity verification of the customer-provided encryption
--   key.
createMultipartUploadResponse_sSECustomerKeyMD5 :: Lens' CreateMultipartUploadResponse (Maybe Text)

-- | If present, specifies the ID of the Amazon Web Services Key Management
--   Service (Amazon Web Services KMS) symmetric customer managed key that
--   was used for the object.
createMultipartUploadResponse_sSEKMSKeyId :: Lens' CreateMultipartUploadResponse (Maybe Text)

-- | If present, specifies the Amazon Web Services KMS Encryption Context
--   to use for object encryption. The value of this header is a
--   base64-encoded UTF-8 string holding JSON with the encryption context
--   key-value pairs.
createMultipartUploadResponse_sSEKMSEncryptionContext :: Lens' CreateMultipartUploadResponse (Maybe Text)

-- | ID for the initiated multipart upload.
createMultipartUploadResponse_uploadId :: Lens' CreateMultipartUploadResponse (Maybe Text)

-- | The server-side encryption algorithm used when storing this object in
--   Amazon S3 (for example, AES256, aws:kms).
createMultipartUploadResponse_serverSideEncryption :: Lens' CreateMultipartUploadResponse (Maybe ServerSideEncryption)

-- | The response's http status code.
createMultipartUploadResponse_httpStatus :: Lens' CreateMultipartUploadResponse Int
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.S3.CreateMultipartUpload.CreateMultipartUpload
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.S3.CreateMultipartUpload.CreateMultipartUpload
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.S3.CreateMultipartUpload.CreateMultipartUpload
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.S3.CreateMultipartUpload.CreateMultipartUploadResponse
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.S3.CreateMultipartUpload.CreateMultipartUploadResponse
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.S3.CreateMultipartUpload.CreateMultipartUploadResponse
instance Network.AWS.Types.AWSRequest Network.AWS.S3.CreateMultipartUpload.CreateMultipartUpload
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.S3.CreateMultipartUpload.CreateMultipartUploadResponse
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Network.AWS.S3.CreateMultipartUpload.CreateMultipartUpload
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.S3.CreateMultipartUpload.CreateMultipartUpload
instance Network.AWS.Data.Headers.ToHeaders Network.AWS.S3.CreateMultipartUpload.CreateMultipartUpload
instance Network.AWS.Data.Path.ToPath Network.AWS.S3.CreateMultipartUpload.CreateMultipartUpload
instance Network.AWS.Data.Query.ToQuery Network.AWS.S3.CreateMultipartUpload.CreateMultipartUpload


-- | Creates a new S3 bucket. To create a bucket, you must register with
--   Amazon S3 and have a valid Amazon Web Services Access Key ID to
--   authenticate requests. Anonymous requests are never allowed to create
--   buckets. By creating the bucket, you become the bucket owner.
--   
--   Not every string is an acceptable bucket name. For information about
--   bucket naming restrictions, see <a>Bucket naming rules</a>.
--   
--   If you want to create an Amazon S3 on Outposts bucket, see <a>Create
--   Bucket</a>.
--   
--   By default, the bucket is created in the US East (N. Virginia) Region.
--   You can optionally specify a Region in the request body. You might
--   choose a Region to optimize latency, minimize costs, or address
--   regulatory requirements. For example, if you reside in Europe, you
--   will probably find it advantageous to create buckets in the Europe
--   (Ireland) Region. For more information, see <a>Accessing a bucket</a>.
--   
--   If you send your create bucket request to the
--   <tt>s3.amazonaws.com</tt> endpoint, the request goes to the us-east-1
--   Region. Accordingly, the signature calculations in Signature Version 4
--   must use us-east-1 as the Region, even if the location constraint in
--   the request specifies another Region where the bucket is to be
--   created. If you create a bucket in a Region other than US East (N.
--   Virginia), your application must be able to handle 307 redirect. For
--   more information, see <a>Virtual hosting of buckets</a>.
--   
--   When creating a bucket using this operation, you can optionally
--   specify the accounts or groups that should be granted specific
--   permissions on the bucket. There are two ways to grant the appropriate
--   permissions using the request headers.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Specify a canned ACL using the <tt>x-amz-acl</tt> request header.
--   Amazon S3 supports a set of predefined ACLs, known as <i>canned
--   ACLs</i>. Each canned ACL has a predefined set of grantees and
--   permissions. For more information, see <a>Canned ACL</a>.</li>
--   <li>Specify access permissions explicitly using the
--   <tt>x-amz-grant-read</tt>, <tt>x-amz-grant-write</tt>,
--   <tt>x-amz-grant-read-acp</tt>, <tt>x-amz-grant-write-acp</tt>, and
--   <tt>x-amz-grant-full-control</tt> headers. These headers map to the
--   set of permissions Amazon S3 supports in an ACL. For more information,
--   see <a>Access control list (ACL) overview</a>.You specify each grantee
--   as a type=value pair, where the type is one of the
--   following:<ul><li><tt>id</tt> – if the value specified is the
--   canonical user ID of an Amazon Web Services
--   account</li><li><tt>uri</tt> – if you are granting permissions to a
--   predefined group</li><li><tt>emailAddress</tt> – if the value
--   specified is the email address of an Amazon Web Services accountUsing
--   email addresses to specify a grantee is only supported in the
--   following Amazon Web Services Regions:<ul><li>US East (N.
--   Virginia)</li><li>US West (N. California)</li><li>US West
--   (Oregon)</li><li>Asia Pacific (Singapore)</li><li>Asia Pacific
--   (Sydney)</li><li>Asia Pacific (Tokyo)</li><li>Europe
--   (Ireland)</li><li>South America (São Paulo)</li></ul>For a list of all
--   the Amazon S3 supported Regions and endpoints, see <a>Regions and
--   Endpoints</a> in the Amazon Web Services General
--   Reference.</li></ul>For example, the following
--   <tt>x-amz-grant-read</tt> header grants the Amazon Web Services
--   accounts identified by account IDs permissions to read object data and
--   its metadata:<pre>x-amz-grant-read: id="11112222333",
--   id="444455556666"</pre></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   You can use either a canned ACL or specify access permissions
--   explicitly. You cannot do both.
--   
--   <b>Permissions</b>
--   
--   If your <tt>CreateBucket</tt> request specifies ACL permissions and
--   the ACL is public-read, public-read-write, authenticated-read, or if
--   you specify access permissions explicitly through any other ACL, both
--   <tt>s3:CreateBucket</tt> and <tt>s3:PutBucketAcl</tt> permissions are
--   needed. If the ACL the <tt>CreateBucket</tt> request is private, only
--   <tt>s3:CreateBucket</tt> permission is needed.
--   
--   If <tt>ObjectLockEnabledForBucket</tt> is set to true in your
--   <tt>CreateBucket</tt> request,
--   <tt>s3:PutBucketObjectLockConfiguration</tt> and
--   <tt>s3:PutBucketVersioning</tt> permissions are required.
--   
--   The following operations are related to <tt>CreateBucket</tt>:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><a>PutObject</a></li>
--   <li><a>DeleteBucket</a></li>
--   </ul>
module Network.AWS.S3.CreateBucket

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateBucket</a> smart constructor.
data CreateBucket
CreateBucket' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe CreateBucketConfiguration -> Maybe Text -> Maybe BucketCannedACL -> BucketName -> CreateBucket

-- | Allows grantee to read the bucket ACL.
[$sel:grantReadACP:CreateBucket'] :: CreateBucket -> Maybe Text

-- | Specifies whether you want S3 Object Lock to be enabled for the new
--   bucket.
[$sel:objectLockEnabledForBucket:CreateBucket'] :: CreateBucket -> Maybe Bool

-- | Allows grantee to write the ACL for the applicable bucket.
[$sel:grantWriteACP:CreateBucket'] :: CreateBucket -> Maybe Text

-- | Allows grantee to list the objects in the bucket.
[$sel:grantRead:CreateBucket'] :: CreateBucket -> Maybe Text

-- | Allows grantee the read, write, read ACP, and write ACP permissions on
--   the bucket.
[$sel:grantFullControl:CreateBucket'] :: CreateBucket -> Maybe Text

-- | The configuration information for the bucket.
[$sel:createBucketConfiguration:CreateBucket'] :: CreateBucket -> Maybe CreateBucketConfiguration

-- | Allows grantee to create new objects in the bucket.
--   
--   For the bucket and object owners of existing objects, also allows
--   deletions and overwrites of those objects.
[$sel:grantWrite:CreateBucket'] :: CreateBucket -> Maybe Text

-- | The canned ACL to apply to the bucket.
[$sel:acl:CreateBucket'] :: CreateBucket -> Maybe BucketCannedACL

-- | The name of the bucket to create.
[$sel:bucket:CreateBucket'] :: CreateBucket -> BucketName

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateBucket</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:grantReadACP:CreateBucket'</a>,
--   <a>createBucket_grantReadACP</a> - Allows grantee to read the bucket
--   ACL.
--   
--   <a>$sel:objectLockEnabledForBucket:CreateBucket'</a>,
--   <a>createBucket_objectLockEnabledForBucket</a> - Specifies whether you
--   want S3 Object Lock to be enabled for the new bucket.
--   
--   <a>$sel:grantWriteACP:CreateBucket'</a>,
--   <a>createBucket_grantWriteACP</a> - Allows grantee to write the ACL
--   for the applicable bucket.
--   
--   <a>$sel:grantRead:CreateBucket'</a>, <a>createBucket_grantRead</a> -
--   Allows grantee to list the objects in the bucket.
--   
--   <a>$sel:grantFullControl:CreateBucket'</a>,
--   <a>createBucket_grantFullControl</a> - Allows grantee the read, write,
--   read ACP, and write ACP permissions on the bucket.
--   
--   <a>$sel:createBucketConfiguration:CreateBucket'</a>,
--   <a>createBucket_createBucketConfiguration</a> - The configuration
--   information for the bucket.
--   
--   <a>$sel:grantWrite:CreateBucket'</a>, <a>createBucket_grantWrite</a> -
--   Allows grantee to create new objects in the bucket.
--   
--   For the bucket and object owners of existing objects, also allows
--   deletions and overwrites of those objects.
--   
--   <a>$sel:acl:CreateBucket'</a>, <a>createBucket_acl</a> - The canned
--   ACL to apply to the bucket.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bucket:CreateBucket'</a>, <a>createBucket_bucket</a> - The
--   name of the bucket to create.
newCreateBucket :: BucketName -> CreateBucket

-- | Allows grantee to read the bucket ACL.
createBucket_grantReadACP :: Lens' CreateBucket (Maybe Text)

-- | Specifies whether you want S3 Object Lock to be enabled for the new
--   bucket.
createBucket_objectLockEnabledForBucket :: Lens' CreateBucket (Maybe Bool)

-- | Allows grantee to write the ACL for the applicable bucket.
createBucket_grantWriteACP :: Lens' CreateBucket (Maybe Text)

-- | Allows grantee to list the objects in the bucket.
createBucket_grantRead :: Lens' CreateBucket (Maybe Text)

-- | Allows grantee the read, write, read ACP, and write ACP permissions on
--   the bucket.
createBucket_grantFullControl :: Lens' CreateBucket (Maybe Text)

-- | The configuration information for the bucket.
createBucket_createBucketConfiguration :: Lens' CreateBucket (Maybe CreateBucketConfiguration)

-- | Allows grantee to create new objects in the bucket.
--   
--   For the bucket and object owners of existing objects, also allows
--   deletions and overwrites of those objects.
createBucket_grantWrite :: Lens' CreateBucket (Maybe Text)

-- | The canned ACL to apply to the bucket.
createBucket_acl :: Lens' CreateBucket (Maybe BucketCannedACL)

-- | The name of the bucket to create.
createBucket_bucket :: Lens' CreateBucket BucketName

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateBucketResponse</a> smart constructor.

--   creating a bucket on the US East (N. Virginia) Region (us-east-1), you
--   do not need to specify the location.
[$sel:location:CreateBucketResponse'] :: CreateBucketResponse -> Maybe Text

[$sel:httpStatus:CreateBucketResponse'] :: CreateBucketResponse -> Int

--   bucket will be created. If you are creating a bucket on the US East
--   (N. Virginia) Region (us-east-1), you do not need to specify the
--   location.
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:CreateBucketResponse'</a>,
--   <a>createBucketResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http status
--   code.
newCreateBucketResponse :: Int -> CreateBucketResponse

--   do not need to specify the location.

-- | Creates a copy of an object that is already stored in Amazon S3.
--   
--   You can store individual objects of up to 5 TB in Amazon S3. You
--   create a copy of your object up to 5 GB in size in a single atomic
--   action using this API. However, to copy an object greater than 5 GB,
--   you must use the multipart upload Upload Part - Copy API. For more
--   information, see <a>Copy Object Using the REST Multipart Upload
--   API</a>.
--   
--   All copy requests must be authenticated. Additionally, you must have
--   <i>read</i> access to the source object and <i>write</i> access to the
--   destination bucket. For more information, see <a>REST
--   Authentication</a>. Both the Region that you want to copy the object
--   from and the Region that you want to copy the object to must be
--   enabled for your account.
--   
--   A copy request might return an error when Amazon S3 receives the copy
--   request or while Amazon S3 is copying the files. If the error occurs
--   before the copy action starts, you receive a standard Amazon S3 error.
--   If the error occurs during the copy operation, the error response is
--   embedded in the <tt>200 OK</tt> response. This means that a <tt>200
--   OK</tt> response can contain either a success or an error. Design your
--   application to parse the contents of the response and handle it
--   appropriately.
--   
--   If the copy is successful, you receive a response with information
--   about the copied object.
--   
--   If the request is an HTTP 1.1 request, the response is chunk encoded.
--   If it were not, it would not contain the content-length, and you would
--   need to read the entire body.
--   
--   The copy request charge is based on the storage class and Region that
--   you specify for the destination object. For pricing information, see
--   <a>Amazon S3 pricing</a>.
--   
--   Amazon S3 transfer acceleration does not support cross-Region copies.
--   If you request a cross-Region copy using a transfer acceleration
--   endpoint, you get a 400 <tt>Bad Request</tt> error. For more
--   information, see <a>Transfer Acceleration</a>.
--   
--   <b>Metadata</b>
--   
--   When copying an object, you can preserve all metadata (default) or
--   specify new metadata. However, the ACL is not preserved and is set to
--   private for the user making the request. To override the default ACL
--   setting, specify a new ACL when generating a copy request. For more
--   information, see <a>Using ACLs</a>.
--   
--   To specify whether you want the object metadata copied from the source
--   object or replaced with metadata provided in the request, you can
--   optionally add the <tt>x-amz-metadata-directive</tt> header. When you
--   grant permissions, you can use the
--   <tt>s3:x-amz-metadata-directive</tt> condition key to enforce certain
--   metadata behavior when objects are uploaded. For more information, see
--   <a>Specifying Conditions in a Policy</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User
--   Guide</i>. For a complete list of Amazon S3-specific condition keys,
--   see <a>Actions, Resources, and Condition Keys for Amazon S3</a>.
--   
--   <b><tt>x-amz-copy-source-if</tt> Headers</b>
--   
--   To only copy an object under certain conditions, such as whether the
--   <tt>Etag</tt> matches or whether the object was modified before or
--   after a specified date, use the following request parameters:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><pre>x-amz-copy-source-if-match</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>x-amz-copy-source-if-none-match</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>x-amz-copy-source-if-unmodified-since</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>x-amz-copy-source-if-modified-since</pre></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If both the <tt>x-amz-copy-source-if-match</tt> and
--   <tt>x-amz-copy-source-if-unmodified-since</tt> headers are present in
--   the request and evaluate as follows, Amazon S3 returns <tt>200 OK</tt>
--   and copies the data:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>x-amz-copy-source-if-match</tt> condition evaluates to
--   true</li>
--   <li><tt>x-amz-copy-source-if-unmodified-since</tt> condition evaluates
--   to false</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If both the <tt>x-amz-copy-source-if-none-match</tt> and
--   <tt>x-amz-copy-source-if-modified-since</tt> headers are present in
--   the request and evaluate as follows, Amazon S3 returns the <tt>412
--   Precondition Failed</tt> response code:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>x-amz-copy-source-if-none-match</tt> condition evaluates to
--   false</li>
--   <li><tt>x-amz-copy-source-if-modified-since</tt> condition evaluates
--   to true</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   All headers with the <tt>x-amz-</tt> prefix, including
--   <tt>x-amz-copy-source</tt>, must be signed.
--   
--   <b>Server-side encryption</b>
--   
--   When you perform a CopyObject operation, you can optionally use the
--   appropriate encryption-related headers to encrypt the object using
--   server-side encryption with Amazon Web Services managed encryption
--   keys (SSE-S3 or SSE-KMS) or a customer-provided encryption key. With
--   server-side encryption, Amazon S3 encrypts your data as it writes it
--   to disks in its data centers and decrypts the data when you access it.
--   For more information about server-side encryption, see <a>Using
--   Server-Side Encryption</a>.
--   
--   If a target object uses SSE-KMS, you can enable an S3 Bucket Key for
--   the object. For more information, see <a>Amazon S3 Bucket Keys</a> in
--   the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <b>Access Control List (ACL)-Specific Request Headers</b>
--   
--   When copying an object, you can optionally use headers to grant
--   ACL-based permissions. By default, all objects are private. Only the
--   owner has full access control. When adding a new object, you can grant
--   permissions to individual Amazon Web Services accounts or to
--   predefined groups defined by Amazon S3. These permissions are then
--   added to the ACL on the object. For more information, see <a>Access
--   Control List (ACL) Overview</a> and <a>Managing ACLs Using the REST
--   API</a>.
--   
--   <b>Storage Class Options</b>
--   
--   You can use the <tt>CopyObject</tt> action to change the storage class
--   of an object that is already stored in Amazon S3 using the
--   <tt>StorageClass</tt> parameter. For more information, see <a>Storage
--   Classes</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <b>Versioning</b>
--   
--   By default, <tt>x-amz-copy-source</tt> identifies the current version
--   of an object to copy. If the current version is a delete marker,
--   Amazon S3 behaves as if the object was deleted. To copy a different
--   version, use the <tt>versionId</tt> subresource.
--   
--   If you enable versioning on the target bucket, Amazon S3 generates a
--   unique version ID for the object being copied. This version ID is
--   different from the version ID of the source object. Amazon S3 returns
--   the version ID of the copied object in the <tt>x-amz-version-id</tt>
--   response header in the response.
--   
--   If you do not enable versioning or suspend it on the target bucket,
--   the version ID that Amazon S3 generates is always null.
--   
--   If the source object's storage class is GLACIER, you must restore a
--   copy of this object before you can use it as a source object for the
--   copy operation. For more information, see <a>RestoreObject</a>.
--   
--   The following operations are related to <tt>CopyObject</tt>:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><a>PutObject</a></li>
--   <li><a>GetObject</a></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Copying Objects</a>.
module Network.AWS.S3.CopyObject

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCopyObject</a> smart constructor.
data CopyObject
CopyObject' :: Maybe ISO8601 -> Maybe ISO8601 -> Maybe Text -> Maybe TaggingDirective -> Maybe MetadataDirective -> Maybe ObjectLockMode -> Maybe ISO8601 -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe (Sensitive Text) -> Maybe RequestPayer -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe StorageClass -> Maybe Text -> Maybe (Sensitive Text) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe ISO8601 -> HashMap Text Text -> Maybe (Sensitive Text) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe (Sensitive Text) -> Maybe ObjectLockLegalHoldStatus -> Maybe Text -> Maybe ObjectCannedACL -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe ServerSideEncryption -> Maybe Text -> BucketName -> Text -> ObjectKey -> CopyObject

-- | Copies the object if it has been modified since the specified time.
[$sel:copySourceIfModifiedSince:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe ISO8601

-- | Copies the object if it hasn't been modified since the specified time.
[$sel:copySourceIfUnmodifiedSince:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe ISO8601

-- | Specifies the 128-bit MD5 digest of the encryption key according to
--   RFC 1321. Amazon S3 uses this header for a message integrity check to
--   ensure that the encryption key was transmitted without error.
[$sel:copySourceSSECustomerKeyMD5:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe Text

-- | Specifies whether the object tag-set are copied from the source object
--   or replaced with tag-set provided in the request.
[$sel:taggingDirective:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe TaggingDirective

-- | Specifies whether the metadata is copied from the source object or
--   replaced with metadata provided in the request.
[$sel:metadataDirective:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe MetadataDirective

-- | The Object Lock mode that you want to apply to the copied object.
[$sel:objectLockMode:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe ObjectLockMode

-- | The date and time at which the object is no longer cacheable.
[$sel:expires:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe ISO8601

-- | Allows grantee to read the object ACL.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
[$sel:grantReadACP:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe Text

-- | Copies the object if its entity tag (ETag) is different than the
--   specified ETag.
[$sel:copySourceIfNoneMatch:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe Text

-- | Specifies the algorithm to use to when encrypting the object (for
--   example, AES256).
[$sel:sSECustomerAlgorithm:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe Text

-- | Specifies the customer-provided encryption key for Amazon S3 to use in
--   encrypting data. This value is used to store the object and then it is
--   discarded; Amazon S3 does not store the encryption key. The key must
--   be appropriate for use with the algorithm specified in the
--   <tt>x-amz-server-side-encryption-customer-algorithm</tt> header.
[$sel:sSECustomerKey:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe (Sensitive Text)
[$sel:requestPayer:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe RequestPayer

-- | Allows grantee to write the ACL for the applicable object.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
[$sel:grantWriteACP:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe Text

-- | Copies the object if its entity tag (ETag) matches the specified tag.
[$sel:copySourceIfMatch:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe Text

-- | Specifies whether Amazon S3 should use an S3 Bucket Key for object
--   encryption with server-side encryption using AWS KMS (SSE-KMS).
--   Setting this header to <tt>true</tt> causes Amazon S3 to use an S3
--   Bucket Key for object encryption with SSE-KMS.
--   
--   Specifying this header with a COPY action doesn’t affect bucket-level
--   settings for S3 Bucket Key.
[$sel:bucketKeyEnabled:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe Bool

-- | If the bucket is configured as a website, redirects requests for this
--   object to another object in the same bucket or to an external URL.
--   Amazon S3 stores the value of this header in the object metadata.
[$sel:websiteRedirectLocation:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe Text

-- | Allows grantee to read the object data and its metadata.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
[$sel:grantRead:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe Text

-- | The account ID of the expected source bucket owner. If the source
--   bucket is owned by a different account, the request will fail with an
--   HTTP <tt>403 (Access Denied)</tt> error.
[$sel:expectedSourceBucketOwner:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe Text

-- | By default, Amazon S3 uses the STANDARD Storage Class to store newly
--   created objects. The STANDARD storage class provides high durability
--   and high availability. Depending on performance needs, you can specify
--   a different Storage Class. Amazon S3 on Outposts only uses the
--   OUTPOSTS Storage Class. For more information, see <a>Storage
--   Classes</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
[$sel:storageClass:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe StorageClass

-- | Specifies the 128-bit MD5 digest of the encryption key according to
--   RFC 1321. Amazon S3 uses this header for a message integrity check to
--   ensure that the encryption key was transmitted without error.
[$sel:sSECustomerKeyMD5:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe Text

-- | Specifies the Amazon Web Services KMS key ID to use for object
--   encryption. All GET and PUT requests for an object protected by Amazon
--   Web Services KMS will fail if not made via SSL or using SigV4. For
--   information about configuring using any of the officially supported
--   Amazon Web Services SDKs and Amazon Web Services CLI, see
--   <a>Specifying the Signature Version in Request Authentication</a> in
--   the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
[$sel:sSEKMSKeyId:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe (Sensitive Text)

-- | Gives the grantee READ, READ_ACP, and WRITE_ACP permissions on the
--   object.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
[$sel:grantFullControl:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe Text

-- | Specifies what content encodings have been applied to the object and
--   thus what decoding mechanisms must be applied to obtain the media-type
--   referenced by the Content-Type header field.
[$sel:contentEncoding:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe Text

-- | The tag-set for the object destination object this value must be used
--   in conjunction with the <tt>TaggingDirective</tt>. The tag-set must be
--   encoded as URL Query parameters.
[$sel:tagging:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe Text

-- | The date and time when you want the copied object's Object Lock to
--   expire.
[$sel:objectLockRetainUntilDate:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe ISO8601

-- | A map of metadata to store with the object in S3.
[$sel:metadata:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> HashMap Text Text

-- | Specifies the Amazon Web Services KMS Encryption Context to use for
--   object encryption. The value of this header is a base64-encoded UTF-8
--   string holding JSON with the encryption context key-value pairs.
[$sel:sSEKMSEncryptionContext:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe (Sensitive Text)

-- | Specifies caching behavior along the request/reply chain.
[$sel:cacheControl:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe Text

-- | The language the content is in.
[$sel:contentLanguage:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe Text

-- | Specifies the customer-provided encryption key for Amazon S3 to use to
--   decrypt the source object. The encryption key provided in this header
--   must be one that was used when the source object was created.
[$sel:copySourceSSECustomerKey:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe (Sensitive Text)

-- | Specifies whether you want to apply a Legal Hold to the copied object.
[$sel:objectLockLegalHoldStatus:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe ObjectLockLegalHoldStatus

-- | Specifies the algorithm to use when decrypting the source object (for
--   example, AES256).
[$sel:copySourceSSECustomerAlgorithm:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe Text

-- | The canned ACL to apply to the object.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
[$sel:acl:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe ObjectCannedACL

-- | Specifies presentational information for the object.
[$sel:contentDisposition:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe Text

-- | The account ID of the expected destination bucket owner. If the
--   destination bucket is owned by a different account, the request will
--   fail with an HTTP <tt>403 (Access Denied)</tt> error.
[$sel:expectedBucketOwner:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe Text

-- | The server-side encryption algorithm used when storing this object in
--   Amazon S3 (for example, AES256, aws:kms).
[$sel:serverSideEncryption:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe ServerSideEncryption

-- | A standard MIME type describing the format of the object data.
[$sel:contentType:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Maybe Text

-- | The name of the destination bucket.
--   
--   When using this action with an access point, you must direct requests
--   to the access point hostname. The access point hostname takes the form
--   <i>AccessPointName</i>-<i>AccountId</i>.s3-accesspoint.<i>Region</i>.amazonaws.com.
--   When using this action with an access point through the Amazon Web
--   Services SDKs, you provide the access point ARN in place of the bucket
--   name. For more information about access point ARNs, see <a>Using
--   access points</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   When using this action with Amazon S3 on Outposts, you must direct
--   requests to the S3 on Outposts hostname. The S3 on Outposts hostname
--   takes the form
--   <i>AccessPointName</i>-<i>AccountId</i>.<i>outpostID</i>.s3-outposts.<i>Region</i>.amazonaws.com.
--   When using this action using S3 on Outposts through the Amazon Web
--   Services SDKs, you provide the Outposts bucket ARN in place of the
--   bucket name. For more information about S3 on Outposts ARNs, see
--   <a>Using S3 on Outposts</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
[$sel:bucket:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> BucketName

-- | Specifies the source object for the copy operation. You specify the
--   value in one of two formats, depending on whether you want to access
--   the source object through an <a>access point</a>:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>For objects not accessed through an access point, specify the name
--   of the source bucket and the key of the source object, separated by a
--   slash (/). For example, to copy the object
--   <tt>reports/january.pdf</tt> from the bucket
--   <tt>awsexamplebucket</tt>, use
--   <tt>awsexamplebucket/reports/january.pdf</tt>. The value must be URL
--   encoded.</li>
--   <li>For objects accessed through access points, specify the Amazon
--   Resource Name (ARN) of the object as accessed through the access
--   point, in the format
--   <tt>arn:aws:s3:&lt;Region&gt;:&lt;account-id&gt;:accesspoint/&lt;access-point-name&gt;/object/&lt;key&gt;</tt>.
--   For example, to copy the object <tt>reports/january.pdf</tt> through
--   access point <tt>my-access-point</tt> owned by account
--   <tt>123456789012</tt> in Region <tt>us-west-2</tt>, use the URL
--   encoding of
--   <tt>arn:aws:s3:us-west-2:123456789012:accesspoint/my-access-point/object/reports/january.pdf</tt>.
--   The value must be URL encoded.Amazon S3 supports copy operations using
--   access points only when the source and destination buckets are in the
--   same Amazon Web Services Region.Alternatively, for objects accessed
--   through Amazon S3 on Outposts, specify the ARN of the object as
--   accessed in the format
--   <tt>arn:aws:s3-outposts:&lt;Region&gt;:&lt;account-id&gt;:outpost/&lt;outpost-id&gt;/object/&lt;key&gt;</tt>.
--   For example, to copy the object <tt>reports/january.pdf</tt> through
--   outpost <tt>my-outpost</tt> owned by account <tt>123456789012</tt> in
--   Region <tt>us-west-2</tt>, use the URL encoding of
--   <tt>arn:aws:s3-outposts:us-west-2:123456789012:outpost/my-outpost/object/reports/january.pdf</tt>.
--   The value must be URL encoded.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   To copy a specific version of an object, append
--   <tt>?versionId=&lt;version-id&gt;</tt> to the value (for example,
--   <tt>awsexamplebucket/reports/january.pdf?versionId=QUpfdndhfd8438MNFDN93jdnJFkdmqnh893</tt>).
--   If you don't specify a version ID, Amazon S3 copies the latest version
--   of the source object.
[$sel:copySource:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> Text

-- | The key of the destination object.
[$sel:key:CopyObject'] :: CopyObject -> ObjectKey

--   <a>$sel:bucketKeyEnabled:CopyObject'</a>,

--   encryption with SSE-KMS.

--   settings for S3 Bucket Key.

--   same Amazon Web Services Region.Alternatively, for objects accessed
--   through Amazon S3 on Outposts, specify the ARN of the object as

--   <tt>arn:aws:s3-outposts:&lt;Region&gt;:&lt;account-id&gt;:outpost/&lt;outpost-id&gt;/object/&lt;key&gt;</tt>.

--   of the source object.

--   destination object.
newCopyObject :: BucketName -> Text -> ObjectKey -> CopyObject

copyObject_expectedSourceBucketOwner :: Lens' CopyObject (Maybe Text)

--   created objects. The STANDARD storage class provides high durability
--   and high availability. Depending on performance needs, you can specify
--   a different Storage Class. Amazon S3 on Outposts only uses the
--   OUTPOSTS Storage Class. For more information, see <a>Storage
--   Classes</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
copyObject_storageClass :: Lens' CopyObject (Maybe StorageClass)

-- | Specifies the 128-bit MD5 digest of the encryption key according to
--   RFC 1321. Amazon S3 uses this header for a message integrity check to
--   ensure that the encryption key was transmitted without error.
copyObject_sSECustomerKeyMD5 :: Lens' CopyObject (Maybe Text)

-- | Specifies the Amazon Web Services KMS key ID to use for object
--   encryption. All GET and PUT requests for an object protected by Amazon
--   Web Services KMS will fail if not made via SSL or using SigV4. For
--   information about configuring using any of the officially supported
--   Amazon Web Services SDKs and Amazon Web Services CLI, see
--   <a>Specifying the Signature Version in Request Authentication</a> in
--   the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
copyObject_sSEKMSKeyId :: Lens' CopyObject (Maybe Text)

-- | Gives the grantee READ, READ_ACP, and WRITE_ACP permissions on the
--   object.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
copyObject_grantFullControl :: Lens' CopyObject (Maybe Text)

-- | Specifies what content encodings have been applied to the object and
--   thus what decoding mechanisms must be applied to obtain the media-type
--   referenced by the Content-Type header field.
copyObject_contentEncoding :: Lens' CopyObject (Maybe Text)

-- | The tag-set for the object destination object this value must be used
--   in conjunction with the <tt>TaggingDirective</tt>. The tag-set must be
--   encoded as URL Query parameters.
copyObject_tagging :: Lens' CopyObject (Maybe Text)

-- | The date and time when you want the copied object's Object Lock to
--   expire.
copyObject_objectLockRetainUntilDate :: Lens' CopyObject (Maybe UTCTime)

-- | A map of metadata to store with the object in S3.
copyObject_metadata :: Lens' CopyObject (HashMap Text Text)

-- | Specifies the Amazon Web Services KMS Encryption Context to use for
--   object encryption. The value of this header is a base64-encoded UTF-8
--   string holding JSON with the encryption context key-value pairs.
copyObject_sSEKMSEncryptionContext :: Lens' CopyObject (Maybe Text)

-- | Specifies caching behavior along the request/reply chain.
copyObject_cacheControl :: Lens' CopyObject (Maybe Text)

-- | The language the content is in.
copyObject_contentLanguage :: Lens' CopyObject (Maybe Text)

-- | Specifies the customer-provided encryption key for Amazon S3 to use to
--   decrypt the source object. The encryption key provided in this header
--   must be one that was used when the source object was created.
copyObject_copySourceSSECustomerKey :: Lens' CopyObject (Maybe Text)

-- | Specifies whether you want to apply a Legal Hold to the copied object.
copyObject_objectLockLegalHoldStatus :: Lens' CopyObject (Maybe ObjectLockLegalHoldStatus)

-- | Specifies the algorithm to use when decrypting the source object (for
--   example, AES256).
copyObject_copySourceSSECustomerAlgorithm :: Lens' CopyObject (Maybe Text)

-- | The canned ACL to apply to the object.
--   
--   This action is not supported by Amazon S3 on Outposts.
copyObject_acl :: Lens' CopyObject (Maybe ObjectCannedACL)

-- | Specifies presentational information for the object.
copyObject_contentDisposition :: Lens' CopyObject (Maybe Text)

-- | The account ID of the expected destination bucket owner. If the
--   destination bucket is owned by a different account, the request will
--   fail with an HTTP <tt>403 (Access Denied)</tt> error.
copyObject_expectedBucketOwner :: Lens' CopyObject (Maybe Text)

-- | The server-side encryption algorithm used when storing this object in
--   Amazon S3 (for example, AES256, aws:kms).
copyObject_serverSideEncryption :: Lens' CopyObject (Maybe ServerSideEncryption)

-- | A standard MIME type describing the format of the object data.
copyObject_contentType :: Lens' CopyObject (Maybe Text)

-- | The name of the destination bucket.
--   
--   When using this action with an access point, you must direct requests
--   to the access point hostname. The access point hostname takes the form
--   <i>AccessPointName</i>-<i>AccountId</i>.s3-accesspoint.<i>Region</i>.amazonaws.com.
--   When using this action with an access point through the Amazon Web
--   Services SDKs, you provide the access point ARN in place of the bucket
--   name. For more information about access point ARNs, see <a>Using
--   access points</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   When using this action with Amazon S3 on Outposts, you must direct
--   requests to the S3 on Outposts hostname. The S3 on Outposts hostname
--   takes the form
--   <i>AccessPointName</i>-<i>AccountId</i>.<i>outpostID</i>.s3-outposts.<i>Region</i>.amazonaws.com.
--   When using this action using S3 on Outposts through the Amazon Web
--   Services SDKs, you provide the Outposts bucket ARN in place of the
--   bucket name. For more information about S3 on Outposts ARNs, see
--   <a>Using S3 on Outposts</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
copyObject_bucket :: Lens' CopyObject BucketName

-- | Specifies the source object for the copy operation. You specify the
--   value in one of two formats, depending on whether you want to access
--   the source object through an <a>access point</a>:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>For objects not accessed through an access point, specify the name
--   of the source bucket and the key of the source object, separated by a
--   slash (/). For example, to copy the object
--   <tt>reports/january.pdf</tt> from the bucket
--   <tt>awsexamplebucket</tt>, use
--   <tt>awsexamplebucket/reports/january.pdf</tt>. The value must be URL
--   encoded.</li>
--   <li>For objects accessed through access points, specify the Amazon
--   Resource Name (ARN) of the object as accessed through the access
--   point, in the format
--   <tt>arn:aws:s3:&lt;Region&gt;:&lt;account-id&gt;:accesspoint/&lt;access-point-name&gt;/object/&lt;key&gt;</tt>.
--   For example, to copy the object <tt>reports/january.pdf</tt> through
--   access point <tt>my-access-point</tt> owned by account
--   <tt>123456789012</tt> in Region <tt>us-west-2</tt>, use the URL
--   encoding of
--   <tt>arn:aws:s3:us-west-2:123456789012:accesspoint/my-access-point/object/reports/january.pdf</tt>.
--   The value must be URL encoded.Amazon S3 supports copy operations using
--   access points only when the source and destination buckets are in the
--   same Amazon Web Services Region.Alternatively, for objects accessed
--   through Amazon S3 on Outposts, specify the ARN of the object as
--   accessed in the format
--   <tt>arn:aws:s3-outposts:&lt;Region&gt;:&lt;account-id&gt;:outpost/&lt;outpost-id&gt;/object/&lt;key&gt;</tt>.
--   For example, to copy the object <tt>reports/january.pdf</tt> through
--   outpost <tt>my-outpost</tt> owned by account <tt>123456789012</tt> in
--   Region <tt>us-west-2</tt>, use the URL encoding of
--   <tt>arn:aws:s3-outposts:us-west-2:123456789012:outpost/my-outpost/object/reports/january.pdf</tt>.
--   The value must be URL encoded.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   To copy a specific version of an object, append
--   <tt>?versionId=&lt;version-id&gt;</tt> to the value (for example,
--   <tt>awsexamplebucket/reports/january.pdf?versionId=QUpfdndhfd8438MNFDN93jdnJFkdmqnh893</tt>).
--   If you don't specify a version ID, Amazon S3 copies the latest version
--   of the source object.
copyObject_copySource :: Lens' CopyObject Text

-- | The key of the destination object.
copyObject_key :: Lens' CopyObject ObjectKey

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCopyObjectResponse</a> smart constructor.
data CopyObjectResponse
CopyObjectResponse' :: Maybe RequestCharged -> Maybe ObjectVersionId -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe (Sensitive Text) -> Maybe (Sensitive Text) -> Maybe ServerSideEncryption -> Maybe CopyObjectResult -> Int -> CopyObjectResponse
[$sel:requestCharged:CopyObjectResponse'] :: CopyObjectResponse -> Maybe RequestCharged

-- | Version ID of the newly created copy.
[$sel:versionId:CopyObjectResponse'] :: CopyObjectResponse -> Maybe ObjectVersionId

-- | If the object expiration is configured, the response includes this
--   header.
[$sel:expiration:CopyObjectResponse'] :: CopyObjectResponse -> Maybe Text

-- | If server-side encryption with a customer-provided encryption key was
--   requested, the response will include this header confirming the
--   encryption algorithm used.
[$sel:sSECustomerAlgorithm:CopyObjectResponse'] :: CopyObjectResponse -> Maybe Text

-- | Indicates whether the copied object uses an S3 Bucket Key for
--   server-side encryption with Amazon Web Services KMS (SSE-KMS).
[$sel:bucketKeyEnabled:CopyObjectResponse'] :: CopyObjectResponse -> Maybe Bool

-- | Version of the copied object in the destination bucket.
[$sel:copySourceVersionId:CopyObjectResponse'] :: CopyObjectResponse -> Maybe Text

-- | If server-side encryption with a customer-provided encryption key was
--   requested, the response will include this header to provide round-trip
--   message integrity verification of the customer-provided encryption
--   key.
[$sel:sSECustomerKeyMD5:CopyObjectResponse'] :: CopyObjectResponse -> Maybe Text

-- | If present, specifies the ID of the Amazon Web Services Key Management
--   Service (Amazon Web Services KMS) symmetric customer managed key that
--   was used for the object.
[$sel:sSEKMSKeyId:CopyObjectResponse'] :: CopyObjectResponse -> Maybe (Sensitive Text)

-- | If present, specifies the Amazon Web Services KMS Encryption Context
--   to use for object encryption. The value of this header is a
--   base64-encoded UTF-8 string holding JSON with the encryption context
--   key-value pairs.
[$sel:sSEKMSEncryptionContext:CopyObjectResponse'] :: CopyObjectResponse -> Maybe (Sensitive Text)

-- | The server-side encryption algorithm used when storing this object in
--   Amazon S3 (for example, AES256, aws:kms).
[$sel:serverSideEncryption:CopyObjectResponse'] :: CopyObjectResponse -> Maybe ServerSideEncryption

-- | Container for all response elements.
[$sel:copyObjectResult:CopyObjectResponse'] :: CopyObjectResponse -> Maybe CopyObjectResult

-- | The response's http status code.
[$sel:httpStatus:CopyObjectResponse'] :: CopyObjectResponse -> Int

--   omitted.

-- | Completes a multipart upload by assembling previously uploaded parts.
--   
--   You first initiate the multipart upload and then upload all parts
--   using the <a>UploadPart</a> operation. After successfully uploading
--   all relevant parts of an upload, you call this action to complete the
--   upload. Upon receiving this request, Amazon S3 concatenates all the
--   parts in ascending order by part number to create a new object. In the
--   Complete Multipart Upload request, you must provide the parts list.
--   You must ensure that the parts list is complete. This action
--   concatenates the parts that you provide in the list. For each part in
--   the list, you must provide the part number and the <tt>ETag</tt>
--   value, returned after that part was uploaded.
--   
--   Processing of a Complete Multipart Upload request could take several
--   minutes to complete. After Amazon S3 begins processing the request, it
--   sends an HTTP response header that specifies a 200 OK response. While
--   processing is in progress, Amazon S3 periodically sends white space
--   characters to keep the connection from timing out. Because a request
--   could fail after the initial 200 OK response has been sent, it is
--   important that you check the response body to determine whether the
--   request succeeded.
--   
--   Note that if <tt>CompleteMultipartUpload</tt> fails, applications
--   should be prepared to retry the failed requests. For more information,
--   see <a>Amazon S3 Error Best Practices</a>.
--   
--   For more information about multipart uploads, see <a>Uploading Objects
--   Using Multipart Upload</a>.
--   
--   For information about permissions required to use the multipart upload
--   API, see <a>Multipart Upload and Permissions</a>.
--   
--   <tt>CompleteMultipartUpload</tt> has the following special errors:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Error code: <tt>EntityTooSmall</tt><ul><li>Description: Your
--   proposed upload is smaller than the minimum allowed object size. Each
--   part must be at least 5 MB in size, except the last part.</li><li>400
--   Bad Request</li></ul></li>
--   <li>Error code: <tt>InvalidPart</tt><ul><li>Description: One or more
--   of the specified parts could not be found. The part might not have
--   been uploaded, or the specified entity tag might not have matched the
--   part's entity tag.</li><li>400 Bad Request</li></ul></li>
--   <li>Error code: <tt>InvalidPartOrder</tt><ul><li>Description: The list
--   of parts was not in ascending order. The parts list must be specified
--   in order by part number.</li><li>400 Bad Request</li></ul></li>
--   <li>Error code: <tt>NoSuchUpload</tt><ul><li>Description: The
--   specified multipart upload does not exist. The upload ID might be
--   invalid, or the multipart upload might have been aborted or
--   completed.</li><li>404 Not Found</li></ul></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The following operations are related to
--   <tt>CompleteMultipartUpload</tt>:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><a>CreateMultipartUpload</a></li>
--   <li><a>UploadPart</a></li>
--   <li><a>AbortMultipartUpload</a></li>
--   <li><a>ListParts</a></li>
--   <li><a>ListMultipartUploads</a></li>
--   </ul>
module Network.AWS.S3.CompleteMultipartUpload

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCompleteMultipartUpload</a> smart constructor.
data CompleteMultipartUpload
CompleteMultipartUpload' :: Maybe RequestPayer -> Maybe CompletedMultipartUpload -> Maybe Text -> BucketName -> ObjectKey -> Text -> CompleteMultipartUpload
[$sel:requestPayer:CompleteMultipartUpload'] :: CompleteMultipartUpload -> Maybe RequestPayer

-- | The container for the multipart upload request information.
[$sel:multipartUpload:CompleteMultipartUpload'] :: CompleteMultipartUpload -> Maybe CompletedMultipartUpload

-- | The account ID of the expected bucket owner. If the bucket is owned by
--   a different account, the request will fail with an HTTP <tt>403
--   (Access Denied)</tt> error.
[$sel:expectedBucketOwner:CompleteMultipartUpload'] :: CompleteMultipartUpload -> Maybe Text

-- | Name of the bucket to which the multipart upload was initiated.
--   
--   When using this action with an access point, you must direct requests
--   to the access point hostname. The access point hostname takes the form
--   <i>AccessPointName</i>-<i>AccountId</i>.s3-accesspoint.<i>Region</i>.amazonaws.com.
--   When using this action with an access point through the Amazon Web
--   Services SDKs, you provide the access point ARN in place of the bucket
--   name. For more information about access point ARNs, see <a>Using
--   access points</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   When using this action with Amazon S3 on Outposts, you must direct
--   requests to the S3 on Outposts hostname. The S3 on Outposts hostname
--   takes the form
--   <i>AccessPointName</i>-<i>AccountId</i>.<i>outpostID</i>.s3-outposts.<i>Region</i>.amazonaws.com.
--   When using this action using S3 on Outposts through the Amazon Web
--   Services SDKs, you provide the Outposts bucket ARN in place of the
--   bucket name. For more information about S3 on Outposts ARNs, see
--   <a>Using S3 on Outposts</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
[$sel:bucket:CompleteMultipartUpload'] :: CompleteMultipartUpload -> BucketName

-- | Object key for which the multipart upload was initiated.
[$sel:key:CompleteMultipartUpload'] :: CompleteMultipartUpload -> ObjectKey

-- | ID for the initiated multipart upload.
[$sel:uploadId:CompleteMultipartUpload'] :: CompleteMultipartUpload -> Text

--   requests to the S3 on Outposts hostname. The S3 on Outposts hostname
--   takes the form
--   <i>AccessPointName</i>-<i>AccountId</i>.<i>outpostID</i>.s3-outposts.<i>Region</i>.amazonaws.com.
--   When using this action using S3 on Outposts through the Amazon Web
--   Services SDKs, you provide the Outposts bucket ARN in place of the
--   bucket name. For more information about S3 on Outposts ARNs, see

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCompleteMultipartUploadResponse</a> smart

data CompleteMultipartUploadResponse
CompleteMultipartUploadResponse' :: Maybe RequestCharged -> Maybe ETag -> Maybe ObjectVersionId -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe BucketName -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe ObjectKey -> Maybe (Sensitive Text) -> Maybe ServerSideEncryption -> Int -> CompleteMultipartUploadResponse
[$sel:requestCharged:CompleteMultipartUploadResponse'] :: CompleteMultipartUploadResponse -> Maybe RequestCharged

-- | Entity tag that identifies the newly created object's data. Objects
--   with different object data will have different entity tags. The entity
--   tag is an opaque string. The entity tag may or may not be an MD5
--   digest of the object data. If the entity tag is not an MD5 digest of
--   the object data, it will contain one or more nonhexadecimal characters
--   and/or will consist of less than 32 or more than 32 hexadecimal
--   digits.
[$sel:eTag:CompleteMultipartUploadResponse'] :: CompleteMultipartUploadResponse -> Maybe ETag

-- | Version ID of the newly created object, in case the bucket has
--   versioning turned on.
[$sel:versionId:CompleteMultipartUploadResponse'] :: CompleteMultipartUploadResponse -> Maybe ObjectVersionId

-- | The URI that identifies the newly created object.
[$sel:location:CompleteMultipartUploadResponse'] :: CompleteMultipartUploadResponse -> Maybe Text

-- | If the object expiration is configured, this will contain the
--   expiration date (expiry-date) and rule ID (rule-id). The value of
--   rule-id is URL encoded.
[$sel:expiration:CompleteMultipartUploadResponse'] :: CompleteMultipartUploadResponse -> Maybe Text

-- | The name of the bucket that contains the newly created object. Does
--   not return the access point ARN or access point alias if used.
--   
--   When using this action with an access point, you must direct requests
--   to the access point hostname. The access point hostname takes the form
--   <i>AccessPointName</i>-<i>AccountId</i>.s3-accesspoint.<i>Region</i>.amazonaws.com.
--   When using this action with an access point through the Amazon Web
--   Services SDKs, you provide the access point ARN in place of the bucket
--   name. For more information about access point ARNs, see <a>Using
--   access points</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
--   
--   When using this action with Amazon S3 on Outposts, you must direct
--   requests to the S3 on Outposts hostname. The S3 on Outposts hostname
--   takes the form
--   <i>AccessPointName</i>-<i>AccountId</i>.<i>outpostID</i>.s3-outposts.<i>Region</i>.amazonaws.com.
--   When using this action using S3 on Outposts through the Amazon Web
--   Services SDKs, you provide the Outposts bucket ARN in place of the
--   bucket name. For more information about S3 on Outposts ARNs, see
--   <a>Using S3 on Outposts</a> in the <i>Amazon S3 User Guide</i>.
[$sel:bucket:CompleteMultipartUploadResponse'] :: CompleteMultipartUploadResponse -> Maybe BucketName

-- | Indicates whether the multipart upload uses an S3 Bucket Key for
--   server-side encryption with Amazon Web Services KMS (SSE-KMS).
[$sel:bucketKeyEnabled:CompleteMultipartUploadResponse'] :: CompleteMultipartUploadResponse -> Maybe Bool

-- | The object key of the newly created object.
[$sel:key:CompleteMultipartUploadResponse'] :: CompleteMultipartUploadResponse -> Maybe ObjectKey

-- | If present, specifies the ID of the Amazon Web Services Key Management
--   Service (Amazon Web Services KMS) symmetric customer managed key that
--   was used for the object.
[$sel:sSEKMSKeyId:CompleteMultipartUploadResponse'] :: CompleteMultipartUploadResponse -> Maybe (Sensitive Text)

-- | If you specified server-side encryption either with an Amazon
--   S3-managed encryption key or an Amazon Web Services KMS key in your
--   initiate multipart upload request, the response includes this header.
--   It confirms the encryption algorithm that Amazon S3 used to encrypt
--   the object.
[$sel:serverSideEncryption:CompleteMultipartUploadResponse'] :: CompleteMultipartUploadResponse -> Maybe ServerSideEncryption

-- | The response's http status code.
[$sel:httpStatus:CompleteMultipartUploadResponse'] :: CompleteMultipartUploadResponse -> Int
